review_title: Cintas is a good place to gain the skills necessary to go somewhere else and actually earn a living.
pros: Good Training Program, Good Reputation in the business community helps lead to other positions, Consistent Stock Performance, their benefits package is pretty decent.
cons:
There are two major downside to working for Cintas. 
The first issue is the pay. The payscale at Cintas for support staff is abysmal. I work in accounting and we have a revolving door of accountants who come here out of college, make next to nothing, but work for two years to get experience and then leave for greener pastures. When questioned about the turnover issue, the CFO Bill Gale said in front of all of accounting/finance that he wouldn't raise the payscale as long as there was a never ending line of people willing to take the lower pay. As you can imagine, this hurt morale and made those of us who have stuck around feel like suckers for taking lower pay. Since that speech six months ago, the turnover rate has doubled within our department. 

The second issue is the culture. The culture is oppressive. You are not an individual, you are a drone. You will not have your own thoughts and feeling, Cintas owns everything about you, and if you step out of line, you will be punished. I have had several higher ups scream at me in front of my staff because I dared to have an independent thought. Here are just a few examples of the mind numbing conformity that is required to function at Cintas. 
Everyone is required by policy to back into their parking spaces, because having some cars backed in and some in head first looks messy. 
You are not allowed to have any food at your desk, because to them you are a little child who will inevitably spill something.  
You must not openly question policy, or the executive staff
Shoes must be polished at all times...I seriously had a supervisor yell at me in front of a whole room full of people because my shoes had a scuff. 
Also, you had better be prepared to work 60-70 hour weeks, forever...because as they say "That is the Cintas Way"

pros: High risk, high reward. You can make a lot of money and get a lot of great experience. The daily grind is the hardest I have ever experienced. They will always ask for more, more, more, but if you succeed, the sky is the limit.
cons: Over tasking specifically in the Service Manager/Supervisor roles has gotten to a point that the Service Reps are suffering. The reps get much less face time and steering because the Managers/Supervisors are simply stretched too thin.

job_title: Market Development Representative in Cincinnati, OH
pros: Work/Life Balance. Car allowance and gas paid for. Career advancement opportunities. Competitive environment. There is a lot of support from the marketing team and Cintas in creating new product lines and making sure we have the best products to sell.
cons: There are too many people cheating the system which raises the president club number and sold amount expectations each year. A lot of MDRs being honest in their business and "selling the right way" eventually get looked at as low performers.

pros: Hard work, kept busy, the co workers were awesome (some bad apples as with any job), would definitely recommend friends to work for them.
cons: Transfers are a pain and ridiculously hard to get through. Even after continuously pursuing transfer, eventually had to give two week notice and went through last day with still no transfer. Applied for 5 more positions with new location I wanted to go through and still had no response. Need to do better about really putting employees first when it comes to those things.

Always have to way for a hire to take a person's job for that person to move for the next person to move, etc. 6 months go by and the most important job never gets filled because it costs a dollar more. Money is the managing factor

review_title: Great Place to Start in Sales - Be Ready to Hustle
job_title: Sales Representative in New York, NY
pros:
Excellent training/preparation. Excellent benefits including health/dental/vision and car package worth ~$12-15K. Diverse product line. Excellent compensation for top-performers. Plenty of opportunity for advancement.

If you are looking to make great money with limited sales experience and/or are a recent graduate, Cintas is an incredible place to start. They will train you very well in the basics of prospecting for and closing business. After your initial 6 months, you will know how 'not to fail' by maintaining an activity model. You will learn decent business acumen and how to identify/engage decision-makers. Finally, you can take advantage of an uncapped commission structure to earn great commissions - note that this doesn't scale with advancement. You will be given the opportunity to learn more logistically-oriented responsibilities, which will give you some versatility when figuring out an internal career-path. It is easy to move between the sales/ops sides once you've had some success in either. As an average sales rep you can expect a starting salary around $35-$50K and total comp in the $85K range. Top performers can exceed $160K in total comp, but note this is not normal - I am presently the #2 ranked rep in my division (192 total reps) and I am on pace for $166,800 this year.
cons:
Outdated sales model. Borderline toxic sales culture. Emphasizes individual results over team success. Difficult sales/ops interplay. Low 'corporate IQ.' Old-world, conservative approach to the sales process. Lack of transparency in managements decisions, particularly when dealing with the front-line revenue generators.

Cintas is an old-school company that doesn't adjust well to change. Stock-price is everything, and you will notice that there is a top-down mentality that essentially conveys a 'do your job and shut your mouth' attitude. Most of management are drawn from the sales-force, which isn't always a good plan because sales people are individualistic by nature an not necessarily suited to teaching/guiding others. You will not find many MBA's in the company, and very few Ivy-leaguers despite compensation in line with 'smarter' companies. This 'brain-drain' creates an environment that can seem oppressive to intellectuals. There is definitely a blue-collar mentality, and even as a sales rep you will be asked to perform 'service' related functions from time to time. I don't think that's a bad thing however. Management emphasizes activity over intelligence and may let you down by skipping over teaching you the nuances of relationship management in favor of a volume-based approach. IF YOU ARE NOT COMFORTABLE WITH COLD-CALLING/DIALING THIS IS NOT A COMPANY FOR YOU.
The commission structure is top-loaded with minimal residual comp, so you have to bring in new business consistently to be successful.

pros: great work life balance because you are done with work at 2. Lots of free time. Lots of cool ssr. 401k matching. really nothing else is good about this job. everyone hates working there.
cons: High pressure for growth. Once you build up a good client bass they do a route split which decreases your pay. management sucks and couldn't care less about forcing you to drive in dangerous situations like ice storms. At the end of the month they will act like your best friend and beg for high amount of sales, but once the new month starts they treat you like crap. They will pee on your back, and won't give you the common courtesy to call it rain.

review_title: Good company but a lot of pressure put on SSRs

Examples: AR issues, customer complaints, getting contracts renewed, constant sales pushes, physically demanding, truck not properly loaded with product needed, fleet maintenance, you have to write your own review, etc

pros:
Pros:

You meet some incredibly hard working people from hispanic backgrounds that are essentially working harder than anyone else in the company.
cons:
Cons:

They act very "excited" (this is a scripted term they use at Cintas) to have you join their team.  Depending on where you live, base salary can be anywhere from 45k to 50k.  During the interview process they tell you about your car package that you will be receiving, your gas card, and your car insurance being paid for.  However, once you're hired, you soon realize that they are also hiring in 4 other people for the exact same role that you were hired in for.  Then the Sales Manager (acting like they already told you this) tells you that you all will be competing for the only territory available and that you'll have to earn the car package, credit card, and car insurance.  I wouldn't recommend taking this job unless you're in desperate need of the money that they pay you to train.  OH AND BY THE WAY--  this *earning your territory" consists of you driving around and selling Cintas products WITHOUT BEING PAID FOR YOUR SALES, WITHOUT BEING COMPENSATED FOR GAS, AND WITHOUT HAVING YOUR INSURANCE PAID FOR.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Grayson, KY

Sometimes you're talked down to. The management team are not leaders they are more like bosses. A great leader will not ask their employee do anything that they are not willing to do themselves.

pros: Cintas puts a great deal of time and resources into their MT program. It does a great job preparing participants to take on a management role after the completion of the program. The exposure to senior leadership is extensive, and the trainings offered by Cintas for MTs are very thorough and insightful. The best aspect is the front line exposure. Rather than learning from an online training or observations, MTs learn from front line experience and working alongside the partners in their jobs on a daily basis.
cons: the production and service aspect of the business do require early morning start times. For non-morning people it can be a difficult transition.

pros: Steady and Stable company... More job security than the average company. Very professional and clean at most facilities.
cons: Benefits & salaries are weak. Cintas will also always struggle getting their headcount and workload balance right... And rewarding the "employee-partners" who go above and beyond to make it happen. Those folks won't stay forever and I think Cintas is okay with that.

pros: They have a great training program. The facilities are clean and safe. Your co-workers or partners, as they are called, are friendly and always willing to help.

review_title: GOOD COMPANY IF YOU ARE NEW TO SALES
job_title: Facility Service Representative in Detroit, MI
pros:
Very Good Training Program would highly recommend for new comers.
Pay is good but the base could be higher.  
Management is touchable from Director to VP and they are all pleasant.
cons:
Indirect micro managing,
long hours 7am-6 pm but salary is based on 40 hours
In their minds if you don't make President Club you are not a good rep.  Advancement is regulated to making President Club several time and if you don't you will be stuck in current position.

pros: Pretty decent benefits: medical, dental, vision, 401k matching. Opportunities for new positions even at other locations. I loved the people I worked with.
cons: Trying to make a career move here or move into a new position is a hard and a long process, but still possible to do. Personally I did not feel like they appreciate their employees with how much they do for them. They are very strict when it comes to company 'policies and procedures'. Sometimes there are a lot of 'cliques' separated by departments.

pros:
- Pretty decent sales training
- it’s a true sales and hunter job so you will learn a ton in a short period of time
- management is good and they will help you as much as they can if you just show that you’re willing to work hard. I’m sure this varies greatly by location
- in my case the team I’m with are all great people
- good stepping stone to move onto something different down the road
- some people may consider the pay to be decent, but if you’re a top performer at Cintas you can make twice as much for another organization
- get a car package which is decent
cons:
Cons
- Base-pay is pretty low, I literally can’t tell a difference in my bank balance when I get the base pay every week. After tax and medical deductions(lowest plan possible) you get like $500 a week in base pay
- they have way too many products and not sufficient training on it.
- they want to you structure the quotes to look better then they really are. A lot of customers will get invoice 30-50% higher then they thought it would be
- They care much more about short term production to boost stock price then doing what’s best for the long term
- waaaaaay too many sales reps for the territory. In my city which has like 300k people living in it we currently have over 10 people selling.
- they tell you to sell products in certain ways and tell the customers things that aren’t really true
- the contracts you sell are ridiculous, who in their right mind would sign a 5 year contract to have expensive soap and mats delivered without knowing if service is any good?
- since I’ve started I’ve been around to existing customers just because I wanted to see if the service was as good as Cintas claims and I’d say about 50% are unhappy, 35% are just pleased enough to keep the service and 15% are happy
- they push sales so hard to sell a ton, which we do but then they don’t have nearly enough drivers. They overload the drivers so bad that it’s inevitable that the service will suffer. One driver can have over 40 stops in one day. They will start at 5am and get back to the plant at like 7pm. I feel terrible for them
- the way the territories are divided sucks. If you have a customer give you a referral you can’t pursue it if it’s not in your zip code.
- if you sell something that’s “too big” you have to pass it On to someone above you and commission is slashed by like 60%
- territories are way over saturated so the only thing you really go after are accounts that your competitors have or account at that used to use Cintas and you have to hope that whoever was unhappy has left by now so you can convince them to sign back up.
- Dress code is ridiculous.
- The commission structure is so complicated and they essentially try to stop sales rep from making more money. They just want to you be able to make just enough to not leave if you’re great
- they give out all kinds of silly awards like a chain for making the most calls one day or most appointments in a week, who cares? Give me more money instead
- you can’t build any customer relationships because you have to hand off new customers to account managers
-  no budget to entertain clients
- the products are just so freaking boring and it’s extremely unrewarding to sell. You’re literally not solving any problems of importance here
- they make you take a ton of online courses every month about common sense things like workplace violence, sexual harassment and more. It’s not the fact that the subjects are unimportant but a sexual harassment course doesn’t need to be 80 slides with no option to skip. All you need is one slide that says “don’t sexually harass your coworkers” ?
- safety training is ridiculous. I don’t need to take a 2 hour class on how to exit or enter my car
- if you have any entrepreneurial tendencies you will hate this job
- have to spend 8 hours per week sitting in a cubicle making calls. It’s about as loud as a football stadium In there
- forget any flexibility or work life balance if you want to earn a decent living.
- they push reps to sell certain products and when they succeed then that product end up being on Back order for months so the rep can’t make the commission on it
- sales process is a joke. If you sell a soap dispenser for example you have to order like 5 different parts with item numbers manually on a little sheet, even after you already typed all the info onto your computer when they signed the contract. Might not sound like much but when you sell 20+ products to one client it can take hours just doing paper work for one client. 
- company only puts focus on quick growth which makes all other areas suffer. The technology provided to the sales team is pre-historic. Walking into the AR department is like taking a trip back to 1995
- you’re just a minion

review_title: Save 10% of your weekly check, you will thank me when you quit
job_title: Service Sales Representative in Valencia, CA
pros:
-Extensive interview process which allows you to get a full perspective of the company, you get to go on a ride-along to experience the job.
-The majority of employees were friendly, helpful, and made for a great environment
-4 day work week (depending on your route, this is probably one of the best perks)
-Paid well, bonus opportunities, commissions, raises, great benefits, etc.
-Some of the best naps I've ever had were on route.
-You get an extra day off. Do yourself a favor, use that day to get a certificate, a degree, learn a new skill, go to the gym, basically anything that will help you find something better. Because in 6 months time, you'll be glad you did.
cons:
-High turnover of drivers, warehouse, and management
-Constant price increases for our customers
-Managers are overworked and extremely stressed, it trickles down to drivers
-They do not invest in the proper tools to do the job right the first time; using the "band-aid" to small problems which escalates to bigger problems, while you get blamed in the end.
-Warehouse crew felt underpaid. There seemed to be a disconnect between drivers and warehouse crew; creating tension and warehouse crew sometimes sabotaged drivers inventory for the next day.
-Expectations are extremely high, constant unrealistic sales demands that come from corporate and are enforced by management.
-Your product for deliveries are missing over 70% of the time, management makes excuses and you have to face customer to explain. Once the product is available, you have to go back to deliver it to the customer on an unscheduled day, which completely slows you down adding a potential 30min-2hrs to your day depending on additional deliveries.

review_title: Good company - if you enjoy working for less than market value and no work/life balance
job_title: Regional Health and Safety Coordinator in Portland, OR
pros: Corporate culture is strong in some aspects and everyone works hard within.  Internal promotion opportunities are always available and if you're flexible with what you do and mobile the doors open even more.  Professional development is the major positive.  I would recommend Cintas from a leadership job standpoint if you are looking for a good opportunity to grow professionally but don't expect the salary to remain competitive.
cons:
As a Regional Health & Safety Coordinator, the position can cover expansive territories requiring up to 70% travel.  Compensation for this position is not adequate and you are paid within the same wage scale (which is not published) regardless of territory size and travel requirements.  This is evident with engagement surveys.  The results of which are discussed for a month or two and then nothing for months after as it seems to die off.

When leaving the company and changing positions for something else, management pretty much ignores you.  No call from corporate directors to express appreciation for a job well done, expectations and goals exceeded - nothing.  No call on your final day from your boss to express anything.  No exit interview provided either which is written in corporate policy so any good or constructive feedback has no outlet and goes unsolicited.  

When you decide to move on to better opportunities or to focus more on family, you go out like a mouse and nothing more than a number.

Cintas pay of frontline workers is adequate in some areas and inadequate in others.  As a whole, Cintas needs to understand it's markets much better with regards to compensation north and south in the organizational structure.

pros:
-Job security is great
-Great benefits including PTO
-Learn a ton
-Diverse environment
-Work next to hard working partners who enjoy and take pride in training you
-Week long training at corporate
cons:
Oh boy, where to start. 

-Production rotation is rough. You'll spend time in both shifts, sometimes third shift (overnight) if necessary.
-Service department will use you to cover routes solo if they're understaffed
-Not the most professional environment,  very blue collar
-Constantly voluntold to take on projects
-Despite having a training plan, management hardly follows it
-Management is predominantly Blue/Green

pros: 4 day work week, decent commission if they actually get around to paying it out. You get to interact with a lot of local businesses so it’s very good for networking purposes.
cons: The Micro managing gets a bit unnecessary. Management will always want you to work harder and longer to make their job easier. They take advantage of their customers and their SSR’s.  Can’t wear shorts in the summertime and the trucks that you work out of easily reach 130 degrees on semi hot days.

review_title: Promotes a culture of fat-shaming and dishonest recruitment practices
pros:
Competitive Salary 
Good Benefits
cons:
Recruitment is trained to only go after "attractive, thin" candidates to uphold their skewed vision of "athleticism." Office environment is extremely exclusive. Management is held to unrealistic expectations. Candidates are put through endless interviews to be disqualified for appearance.  There is no work life balance.  Meetings start as early at 4AM and you will be expected to stay until 8/9PM.  Sexist practices involving the wardrobe women are "expected" to wear. 

I am truly surprised by the positive reviews of this company.  It was an overall, terrible, unethical place to work.

review_title: Great place to grow your career!
pros: Worldwide locations; no shortage in advancement opportunities; positive environment; competitive salary for management positions; great work/life balance; weekends off; self-training opportunities for your position; trust in your leadership capability. If you have a positive attitude you will clearly see the great things Cintas offers.
cons: It's not a perfect place but in comparison to other companies, Cintas is a great company to work.  Starting hourly pay for plant position workers can be more competitive.

review_title: Good Company with challenges not uncommom to all b2b service companies.
pros: Recognized for valuing its most precious resource - "partners".  Works hard to communicate with partners across all levels of the organization.  Rewards top performers, employes concistancy and fairness when coaching performance, managing disciplinary matters or partner terminiation.
cons: Business model is built on the efforts low wage partners in a majority of the production and service positions critical to service customers.

review_title: Stay away unless you just want the name on your resume.
job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Bedford Park, IL
pros: It's a paycheck, good benefits.
cons: Horrible Management, they determine if you succeed or fail by manipulating accounts.  HR is useless.  Managers are dishonest and will throw you or anyone under the bus and will lie to your face.  Could be a decent place to work if new managers who knew how to run a department were in place. The head manager has no education and is intimidated by anyone who does.  They do not encourage or support higher education

job_title: SSR (Service Sales Representative) in Bedford Park, IL
pros:
- 4 Day workweek
- Good Pay and Benefits
- SSRs work at their own pace without any direct supervision
- Management staff and GM are very good at my location
- Lots of upward mobility. If you do not like your current position then there is always a different career direction for you to take.
cons:
- You will be hot in the summer and cold during the winter depending on your location.
- Physically demanding and dirty job that may not be for everyone

review_title: Work Hard. Get Paid. Make your own work life balance through your sales efforts.
pros: If you like to work hard, with a blue collar work ethic for white collar pay, then Cintas Sales is for you.
cons: Technology is lagging and slowly being improved which could be much more effective in implementing solutions to help streamline sales and operations.

pros: This place is ok. I don't think its the best place to work but it is definately not the worst. I really hated doing the phone blocking while the managers just sat there and did nothing. However, the pay was good for someone just getting out of college. I would tghink very hard and carefully before you go to work for Cintas, because it is a subpar company. You should be well advised on selling products door to dorr. I felt like a used car salesman selling their products. Overall, it is not a good job, you can do a lot better
cons: Selling door to door everyday

review_title: Good company for growth, bad company for social life
pros: Cintas was great place for advancement, in my three years there I received two promotions.  A lot of the managers were younger and for the most part great to work with.
cons: In every position I worked, it was very demanding.  I don't mind putting in the hours but the 60-70 hours I was working for a long stretch was a little overbearing, especially only getting paid for 40 of those hours.  It made having a social life a challenge at times.

review_title: Dirty business, but the best at it.
job_title: Customer Service Manager in Dallas, TX
pros: Great morale at the management level. The company has a unique history of hard work and humble beginnings that transformed into a fortune 1000 company. Strongly support promoting from within. Everyone from the drivers to the CEO have to go through training in the plant, doing the dirty jobs to build up respect for the frontline partner.
cons: Lower skill workers and drivers don't buy in to the corporate culture. Makes it hard to keep people motivated. The company is so afraid of becoming unionized that they tend to dismiss poor performance and fail to discipline those with infectious, negative attitudes.

review_title: Can be an ok place to work.
pros: Great benefits package.  not in an office all day, for the most part.  flexiable schedule if need be.
cons: shady unethical management practices.  DO NOT vent to peers about anything cintas or personal life related.  you have to keep track of your paycheck because more likely than not you will not be paid correctly.  if offered a management job take it.  if not, move on.

job_title: Global Supply Chain in Chicago, IL
pros: Benefits are good and pay just ok
cons:
-too many micro managers 
-managers will write you up over the smallest thing
-they asked your feedback, but will use it against you as being negative if not what they want to hear
-very stressful environment, can't trust anyone, seems as if everyone is there to throw you under the bus
-If you want to survive you will have to become a robot and just say yes to whatever even if you disagree.
-way too many women managers- they are control freaks.

review_title: Cintas does an excellent job of recruiting top level talent, but a poor job of retaining them.
pros: Excellent training programs, relatively recession proof industry, good communication of corporate vision to partners from CEO (and VPs, executives)
cons: Work life balance is not valued at this company.  Compensation is never adapted to the market, or talent level.  Corporate vision is not followed at local/regional levels.  Making bonus at any cost is the name of the game, even at a sacrifice of ethics or employee well-being.

review_title: Must plan to work very hard!!!
pros: Cintas is a very stable company
cons: Company keeps strict control over spending. You will never have enough of what you need to ever slow down. you must be at 100% or higher every second or you fall behind and then have to work longer to catch up. Supervisors are salary and are expected to work 10-11 hrs a day minimum.

review_title: Great job if family is not important...
pros: Good starting pay, chances to advance in the company, innovative products and a well established profitable company, great benefits and good talented people, great corporate culture.
cons: Hard to balance family/work life, stressful job, always changing KPIs so they are out of reach, will restructure pay plans if a SSR is performing well so they are less compensated, once they identify someone is not meeting expectations - they become a target instead of trying to work with the partner.

pros: Culture, values, industry leader when it comes to products/services/processes, great people, great leadership, competitive atmosphere, competitive pay, tenured partners who are good at what they do. Great training/development opportunities. If you're driven and a culture fit, the sky is the limit.
cons: The industry as a whole is a little behind in technology and technological advancements aren't a major priority, which makes some tasks/processes more difficult than they need to be. Work/life balance can be tough depending on role, market conditions, etc.

pros:
Pay is based on performance and can be very good if you beat numbers
Promote from within(most of the time) so there's a career path
A lot of great people
Great training for people with no experience
Great stepping stone
cons:
Sales and service relationships aren't great as each sides goals/pay incentives don't align
Certain upper management is unethical and conniving 
What have you done for me lately mentality and look to get rid of people quickly (including peak performers who have an off year, or are not yes sir employees)
There is no work life balance to be successful

pros: The people you work with are great. The best group of peers you could ask for.
cons: Basically everything else. Upper management and most of management is not qualified. Good luck getting promoted unless you stay for 25 years. As far as IT goes, with exception of a few, all director and above are clueless. Turnover is high. They try and minimize that fact by adding headcount. Not a very class organization. Just a bad place. I wouldn't buy their product or work for them. Worst company I've ever worked for. If they suck you in prepare for the bait and switch.

review_title: An Ok Company That Could Be Great
pros:
- Fairly friendly people
- Nice office setting. Constantly improving and updating the building and surroundings
- Never a shortage of potlucks
- Diversity
- Insurance benefits and incentives to reduce out of pocket costs. (pretty decent per independent, third-party audit of company and other national companies, shown by HR to employees)
- Continued business growth ("job security")
cons:
-Pay (lower than average compared to other national companies and was confirmed by independent, third-party audit. Shown by HR to employees)
- Could not move up higher in company without relocating, accrued paid time is still separated by vacation/sick time instead of lump PTO, not enough vacation/sick time (also verified in company audit, lower than national average for comparable companies)
- Lengthy application process that does not seem to attract or retain knowledgeable and competent candidates 
- High turnover in office positions seems to match those in plant and production roles
- Requests for employees to refer people they know to apply and are rarely called to interview
- HR doesn't ever seem very knowledgeable about HR related questions
- Management can be less than professional, especially when the big boss is away. Lots of horseplay, throwing footballs/balls indoors, and just very little care that others were working and possibly on phone calls
- Management did not train employees and would always send those who would come to them for answers (as they should) to coworkers who were busy trying to do their own jobs
- Always tried to find ways to circumvent the restrictions set in place by the systems we used to do special things for customer even though the issues would show up in discrepancy reporting

review_title: Best place to work in the world.
job_title: Service Sales Representative in Houston, TX
pros: Great Company, Great people and a positive atmosphere. Great culture. One of the best place I have every worked.Love the commit to family values and how we are encouraged to put our family s first. Theirs also a great deal of time an energy spent on growing the company. Which is excellent for the possibilities career advancement. We at Cintas are professional in ever thing we do and are never satisfied with mediocrity.
cons:
The only down side to Cintas is that being it is a team environment when other don't pull their weight it can affect everyone.
Other than that it is a great place to work.

review_title: Excited in the begining and then could no longer take the excuses I was making for Cintas
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Tustin, CA
pros: 4 day work week, healthcare benefits, weekly pay period, bonus incentives, profit sharing, uniforms and shoes provided, minimum technical skills needed to perform job, 49 day training period; paid vacations
cons: 60+ hour work week; insignificant group rate discount on healthcare benefits; murky, unexplained payroll system; break-even profit sharing due to poor reputation; employee uniforms are often lost indefinately through employee laundry service; vacations difficult to schedule due to understaffing and undertraining; 49 day training often ends up in new employee filling in for an injured employee without ever recieving proper training; super wasteful: lots of overlapping processes and unwarranted printing

pros: Work here if you are a guy.
cons:
I worked as an Apparel Designer in their National Account Sales Division in Chicago. The department is full of ignorant people who really believe what they are doing is fashion forward. Unless you are the top 3 people they treat you like dirt and pin you against your co-workers. They are very shady. 

Also, If you are a girl forget about advancing to the top! All of upper management are cocky men. The corporate culture is more like brainwashing they call it "drinking the Kool-Aid" and are proud of it. Ladies you have to wear hose in the summer months just so you don't show legs. 

Lastly, the office is out by midway (please don't get shot!).

review_title: Good Product, poor management, high turnover
pros: Good experience with training. Reputable company and great resume builder.
cons: Very high turnover, poor management, lacking empathy, all about the numbers. If you close a deal its not as much rewarded as it is looked at as what you could have done better. Nothing is ever good enough. Communication lacks. Unethical sales reps are rewarded.

pros: Only real pros are the four day work week, they give you boots, and uniforms. They will also feed you one day a month but it will be cold by the time you get back from your route.
cons: You will not make the money they claim. They use under handed business tactics to raise prices on their customers that are all under contract. They supervisors don't want to look the customer in the eye so they force the Route driver (SSR\pack mule) to handle everything and your job is on the line if you can't manipulate your customers. I would rather shovel horse crap with a clear conscience than work for this shady company!

review_title: Great opportunity and resume builder, but not a terrific culture
pros:
Encourages a good work ethic
Reasonable base-pay compensation
Encourages reserve-component duty
cons:
Corporate culture is oppressive (Drink the kool-aid!)
A lot of flavor-of-the-week initiatives/ideas (today the focus of our business is etc.)
Still waiting for payment of performance based bonus (60 plus days after end of fiscal year, and don't get me started on the fact I haven't even seen a quarterly one since I've been there!)

review_title: Hard work, but love the company
pros: The partners at Cintas are wonderful. The people at my location really seem like they care about me doing well. As a management trainee, I get to rotate through different areas of the business. I've only been here for 2 months, but I already appreciate the hard work that the partners do in the plant, on the road, and in the office. It's by far some of the hardest work that I've done and I think it's worth it!
cons: Hours vary on the day and the rotation for management trainees. I've been informed that I should get ready for some really long days.

review_title: Hard work will pay off, I hope
pros: Great hours, I like my co-workers, job security, paid weekly, and managers that actually care about teaching you how to advance your career with Cintas. I think my manager really wants me to become a better leader
cons: Pay could be a lot better, no vacation/sick time in first year. It gets very hot in the summer months. Teamwork between drivers and plant partners could be better. I feel like we clean up their mess when they bring back their unorganized trucks.

pros: The hours are stable and they do value family issues and try to keep the people they have in there workplace. Good benefits, very friendly enviroment.
cons: Bad warehouse, safety first  was the motto but seemed only when good for cintas well being. Pay was bad and not good enough for all the work related stress put on the warehouse workers. People aren't held accountable for what they do and so everyone is in trouble for the team effort. Partners are treated better than others so favoritism was acknowledged. Atmosphere felt as if nothing would ever go right and your position and growth is static

job_title: Sales Representative in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Well established, Great Training, Positioned in the market for success. You walk into any facility and it is almost guaranteed that Cintas has a presence.
cons: Large Company with big corporate waters and politics to navigate. They limit the earning potential of their sales which is never a good thing when you have top performers. The best will go to where they can make the most.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Charles, MO
pros: Cintas is a great place to work.  My managers were great mentors.  They listened to me and were always there for me if I had a concern.  They constantly evaluate pay and want to make sure they are on top of current marketplace trends. Cintas is a very transparent company.  They make sure that employees know where they stand and how they can improve.  This is just a part of their great culture.
cons: You do have a large workload but this isn't really a "con" because you will never be bored working at Cintas.

review_title: Good pay but very stressful mentally and physically
pros: Good pay, 401k, holidays off, 4 day work week.
cons:
Very Poor management / NO HELP
Practically everything is put on the SSRs shoulders because management  doesn’t get involved. Management already has their person picked out for a promotion before the job is posted. So if you aren’t asked ahead of time you have no chance for that position.

pros: Fellow Employees, pay, culture, comp
cons:
Constant Pay/Compensation changes disguised as good for the SSR, Constant price changes that are not made public to the SSR or the customers (deceptive?). Managers try to run a location on the cheap, as their yearly bonus depends on this. Ie....no service manager the Operations Manager can handle everything.
Office Partners not being held accountable for their mistakes that affect you and your customers.

review_title: Great portfolio of products, Stable Company, Pay is Ok, Standards and Pressure to produce a number insane.
pros:
Solid, profitable company. Good starter course for learning sales. Pay is not bad and car package is top notch. Not as good as it was, but not bad. Every year they lower the commission structure and raise the number, but that's just the way it goes in sales. Cintas is not a special and unique snowflake I'm sure when it comes to that. If you don't know how good the commission was 4 years ago, you won't be bothered by how much its gone down anyway right?

Industry leader if you go into the uniform sales. Steer clear of the Doc Shredding(we just sold to major competitor Shred-It) and Deep Clean which is almost like a start up company with a niche customer base that is tough to crack into, with minimal marketing support. 

Have created new sales positions, so if you are a top performer you can branch out into more industry specific/Matrix sales positions.
cons:
You are always just a number no matter how long you have been here. . High activity is an absolute must. You won't last otherwise. Don't even waste your time applying. We are held to such a high sales number now, if you take your foot off the gas, you will pay for it. 
Expensive product, always on the higher side compared to competition. The flip side is you have better quality products, so it's justified, but it does make it tough. Locking someone in a 3-5 year contract is tough as well, but that's an industry norm. 
Not family friendly at all! They expect you to put everything to the side to hit that number. If you are a female (which i am not) and you want to start a family, I would suggest you tread lightly.

pros: Great benefits package at a low cost. Decent stepping stone for new mechanics.
cons: No organization within maintenance department. Management tried to micromanage every aspect of our work. Lots of brown nosing going on here. They preach culture all day long but thats just for show. I suppose it would be decent if you held a first shift position but if you worked second or nights forget about it. No structure, no opportunity for advancement. Production workers were treated terribly by management. All the procedures and policies made repairs very difficult at times.

pros:
Pay
Career advancement if you are willing to drink the kool-aid
cons:
Questionable / unethical practices.
On one hand the corporate office preaches honesty and integrity, but at the location level they turn a blind eye to employees who make unethical or dishonest decisions because bonuses are heavily weighted to sales growth. 
Sales Reps and SSR's are not compensated with the customer's best intentions in mind. Sales reps get paid by how much product sticks in the account for 4 weeks, and the ramifications of those poor decisions are left to the Service team to clean up and enforce the contract.
Major conflict between Service and Sales teams. 
Poor leadership at the location.
Regularly encourage Service Reps to work through injuries due to being short staffed.

job_title: Facility Services Sales Representative in Tulsa, OK
pros: Good leadership overall, car package, good health insurance, decent product
cons: highest cost product, depending on leadership could be difficult, hard to sell on value when you sell toilet paper

review_title: A tough job that is made harder than it is...
pros: Great company. Stock Price has done nothing but shoot up. It is the top company in the rental industry, so definitely work for them if you want to do this job. AMAZING training program. You will learn the great basics to Sales and they invest heavy into training you weekly. I would almost compare the job to boot camp for sales.  If you do well too, the money can be good. Even if you go through the motions, it's not bad money.
cons: It's a very hard industry. There is never really as many prospects out there as they tell you. I would argue the industry as a whole has a negative view in many other business eyes. Companies who have tried Uniform programs usually will have been burned by them at some point, and it's hard to get those people back. Selling Uniforms I think is much tougher than selling Facility Services. If I could I offer advice, if you have the choice, sell FS, not uniforms. FS you will always have someone brand new opening and many more prospects...which is where you make money....new customers.  Uniforms, you just have more working against you. Also, this is a tough job, and like other jobs, if you have a manager who you don't feel is helping you...the job is even tougher. You can't control who manages you, but Cintas has to realize better who they put in that position.

review_title: I love the principles but hate the execution
pros:
Awesome pay for a job that only requires a GED or above.

The corporate culture (as written, maybe not executed) is fantastic.

Awesome benefits.

Very clear expectations business-wise

Career paths for the politically/boot-licking minded.
cons:
Ethical Issues:

Excessive emphasis on short-term revenues over longer-term considerations.

Desire for simple, “quick fix” solutions to ethical problems.

Unwillingness to take an ethical stand that may impose financial costs.

Consideration of ethics solely as a legal issue or a public relations tool.

Lack of clear procedures for handling ethical problems.

Responsiveness to the demands of shareholders at the expense of other constituencies

The extent of my ethical training was "We have high principles and moral values," but beyond that, it was a sheet that said that we don't steal from the company or customers and a power point slide that said, "Diversity matters."  

Diversity in personality, thought/communication style, and mental health are important as well as the legally mandated categories.

I believe that the execution on the location level is hit or miss.  Most of the time it misses.  Sink or swim and lack of actual development.  I had quite a few managers in the short time I attended Cintas.  The lack of actual development shows.

I'd suggest moving toward an integrity-based ethics program, as opposed to a purely compliance-based ethics program.


"Every partner is continuously engaged in improving safety." (UNLESS IT COSTS US BUSINESS)  Keeping partners unilaterally safe should be a higher priority on GM and SM training.  I was pushed a few times to continue endangering myself in a hazardous environment before they realized I could have legal grounds if they pushed anymore.


The one-on-one communication could be improved as well.  I had a silent jerk, a dunce, and a clueless jock in the little time I was here.  Learn to communicate to adults on a human level.  Being clueless jerks 24/7 will run off talent.

review_title: Why to and not to work for Cintas
pros: Cintas has some of the strongest leadership for any company I have ever worked for.  They truley care about all of their employee partners.
cons: The downside of working for Cintas is be prepared for Corporate personnel to constantly be looking for problems that often don't exist.  They take into consideration small complaints too much which opens the doors for front line partners to feel they can control what management stays and which ones go.

pros: Good benefits....see what happens going forward.  Ok pay.
cons: Work/Life balance and management is a joke.  Only focused on bottom line and not focused on the people that actually do the work in the trenches.

review_title: The good, the bad, the ugly...
pros: Pay was not bad for awhile, co-workers were friendly for the most part.
cons: Economy has hit this place hard.  Most corp departments have been outsourced or are going to be outsourced. Not many long term partners left, no one really knows what the different divisions are or what they do.  Management bonuses based on Six Sigma 'made up' numbers.  Corp offices are a museum now, big shell of a building with no one in it.

job_title: Sales Service Representative in Deerfield Beach, FL
pros: Company has a great objective: We will exceed our customers expectation to maximize the long term value of Cintas for its shareholders and working partners!
cons: Not too many cons as I am only five months into this positions. Some working partners not pulling their own weight, but with the position being a part commission position, they are only hurting themselves and potentially helping others who are willing to pick up the accounts that the other cannot get to.

review_title: Overall was a great experience and learned different areas of the business and the structure within.
job_title: Route Skipper and SSR Trainee in Union, NJ
pros: Four day work week and no set end time. When you finish your route or duties you are free to go.
cons: Some leadership lacked accountability and left you out to dry at certain points. You had to fend for your self at different points to get by

pros: Cintas is a very stable company and industry leader.  Constantly improving product offerings.  Cintas is run very well and understands and executes it's business model.  Even as a leader in the industry there is always a competitive urgency to perform better and increase value for the customer.
cons: Advancement opportunities can be frustratingly slow despite high levels of performance.  Pay is average at best, though benefits can cover some of the pay gap. Work/life balance not ideal in most management positions.

review_title: Politics, cronyism, random paycuts but wait you're a "Partner"
pros: If you want to put in more hours there is almost always extra money to be made to by picking up extra customer assignments. Medical coverage is great with BlueCross but a bit higher cost than average. If you get a good route, work life balance is great. Lots of low level training if you do not know anything about everything. Almost anyone with people skills and basic business sense can do the job. Never seen layoffs, even when the market went south in 2009. Products are great quality and easy to sell. You get to take home a company van (billboard sign attached).
cons: I could write a book here. Basically Cintas is money hungry and is willing to do whatever to hit arbitrary sales goals regardless of ethics. Being a big corporation they do whatever they can to appear to be honest and forthcoming but it is not the real truth. Pay is not bad but nowhere near what they tell you that you will make. Pay cuts come randomly if management thinks you are doing too well and they will make up whatever excuse they can to say its not true. There is lettle to no appreciation shown to those that do amazing things, just a question of "Now what are you going to do next month?" Promotions only go to friends and brown nosers of management not to whom is most qualified for the job. No innovation, no team work, no help/coverage for sick or vacation time, and  top heavy management that is out of touch with the customer base and front line staff.

review_title: Unless you want to live in Cincinatti, no career potential
pros:
They have good benefits
They are industry leaders 
They care a lot about employee safety 
No fear of layoffs for the most part
cons:
They pay pretty low for most of the positions they have 
They don't treat employees fairly when thinking of promotional opportunity, and tend to have a "good old boys network"
Unless you want to live in Cincinatti, there is not promotional opportunity for most professional jobs

review_title: Your worth to the company is summed up in your weekly sales number.
job_title: Facility Services Sales Representative in San Francisco, CA
pros: Competitive base salary, great bonus and commission structure, nice car package, they pay for your insurance, cell phone allowance, lap top, air card, autonomy to make your own schedule.
cons: It's only, "What have you done for me lately?" Also, the work/life balance is a joke. They expect you to work around the clock. Although they'll never say it, it's really the crux of their, "Corporate Culture."

pros: Good benefits, clean environment, the seasoned employees are very friendly
cons: Current supervisors/managers do not take well to outsiders (new supv/mgrs) coming onto their turf. Training consisted of a day or so in each area but it was up to you to find the right person to actually show you the ropes. After that you are all on your own. Learn quick if you are new. They want someone to come into the company, learn the business, and fix the mess they have created over the last 20+ years, very quickly. Many of the fellow supervisors look down their nose at you because you invaded their area. One of the worst experiences I have ever had.

review_title: Great Company to Cut your teeth in sales
job_title: Uniform Sales Representative in Little Rock, AR
pros: Large company with corporate structure. Freedom with schedule setting own appointments and cold calls. Able to learn the ropes out among a wide variety of customers. Great start in B2B sales.
cons:
Reps burn out quick with the weekly grind of trying to set appointments and do cold calls. Customer base is usually already in a contract with one of the many competitors.. Aramark, Unifirst, Ameripride, National Linen, etc. 
Also, there is a stern aristocratic culture. No facial hair, shirt and tie daily. Company events prohibit any adult beverages and laughter.

pros: Great concept , product seems like it is a doable sale. Good benefits package offered. Recognizable name in the field.
cons: Interview experience is long and they take days to get back to you. I got all the way to the end of the process and pretty much had the job and they chose someone younger.

pros: Good for career growth, the company is continually growing.  Benefits are better than most, especially the Medical plans and the cost thereof, as well as a great 401(k), Match and Employee Stock Ownership Plan (ESOP).
cons: Pay not always competitive and can sometimes be made to feel like a number in a company the size of ours.  College degrees highly valued yet no tuition reimbursement plan offered.

pros: 4 day work week, Major Holidays off, Stock/401k options.
cons:
Great people in the wrong positions, lack of collaboration and communication between departments. 

Training could be improved, technology is lacking, turnover, lack of integrity with customers/partners!  

Not open to suggestions to improve the workplace and lack of team building with all departments. 

Sales could be awesome with the right training and insight from actual SSR's.

Old plant a new plant is needed asap! Meetings are a joke. Pay tactics are disappointing.

pros:
1. Great Company!! 
2. Cintas has very good Benefits
cons:
1. Can be very long days/hours. 
2. If you do not have a College Degree they will NOT promote you to be a Service Manager or go into Sales.

pros: Goal oriented company with the training to be successful in sales. Does a good job showing you the tactics and value propositions to start a career in sales.
cons: Zero work life balance, unrealistic expectations, and limited upward mobility. Once you become a manager, there are very few places you can go. The company operates in different silos between operations, the plant, and sales. If you are in one, transitioning to another successfully is very difficult.

pros: Stable company, great people, good COO, offers a 401(k), good car package
cons: Hospitality division leadership or lack thereof, little to no advancement opportunities within that division, overly conservative both culturally and financially, president's club trip is nothing special, health insurance and 401(k) match could be more generous.

pros: Working for Cintas was a rewarding experience. First, they are pretty dominant and have a good reputation in the Service Industry. Second, the work is rewarding and partners are recognized for their contributions. Finally, there is a lot of opportunity to work your way up and it is a good resume builder.
cons: Communication among divisions is almost non-existent. The advertising/promotions/marketing is poor. I know the company really doesn't rely on advertising but what little advertisements we did have were a step behind.

pros: Builing relationships with partners and customers
cons:
Cheat and rip off customers
Work Life Cycle
Unappreciated
Favortism
Upper Management

pros: 4 day work week, good health benefits, weekends off
cons: Opportunity to advance and diversity is spoken of in initial interviews upon hire, but the opposite is true once one gets the job.  Not much advancement available for minorities past the SM position.   Still operates like a good ole boy company.  Low pay and next to impossible numbers to hit in order to get raises.  One could work years with no raise and are told, "if you want to make more, then sell more".  Location spends very little on rewarding SSR's for hitting goals or SSR of the month.  No equal equity for partners in sharing location profits and management is always crying broke.  You are encouraged to keep your opinions and thoughts to yourself.  If you do say anything, then you're isolated and counseled for having a bad attitude or corrupting others around you.  In reality though, most of the other SSR's hold similar thoughts but are either afraid to say something or have been given the same isolation tactic by management, so they just stop voicing their thoughts.  Management is reactive verses proactive to customer issues.  Product and rental pricing is all over the board for the customer and most times the small customer is hit the hardest with outrageous pricing.  The SSR is expected to not only add on products during the contract period, but also resign the customer or it could be held against the SSR in hitting monthly bonus.  Much of Cintas's lost business could be resolved by fair pricing and not increasing prices for the customer 2 or more times a year throughout their agreement.  Cintas attempts so many gimmicks and programs to entice the partners in ways to increase sales, but the rewards don't justify the extra time and effort needed to make them work.   It's called, "kool-aid of the month". HR is totally company biased in it's thinking and quick to note any negative issue in one's file.  The company is all numbers based and partners are second, when in fact, it's the partners that make the company survive.  Partners are usually steered like cattle in whatever direction Cintas deems is the right path, even if it doesn't work.  After awhile, we're steered another way because the previous direction didn't work.  (Cintas rarely admits mistakes or program failures)  The plant is literally run like a sweat shop. Sick time is available but if you don't use it, you lose it.  Why not pay an incentive to partners who don't use all or a portion of their sick time.  Maybe they wouldn't try to use it all up during the year.  Corporate is out of touch with what goes on the average route and the hard work put in by the SSR to compensate for the inadequate and often incompetent leadership of the local plant.

pros: The culture is very good. There is never a lack of training, (sometimes too much), but overall it is beneficial to the division. There was never a lack of opportunity to advance (as long as you are willing to relocate).
cons: You have to be careful what you say and to whom. You have to know who your friends are. When it comes to partner engagement, it's a laughing matter. If you are on the corporate side, which I was, there is zero partner engagement.

review_title: Awesome job for physical fitness; you WILL leave that job in better shape you started.
pros:
A.  4 Day Work is amazing, especially if you lucky enough to get a Friday or Monday, usually goes to veterans/route setup.  This allows for an awesome work-life balance (if your in shape, if not... your going to hate life for awhile).
B.  Training is something like 3 months, it may be different now.  They have VERY VERY strict training guidelines, if you fail to progress or you struggle on the final interview (for a route, yep.. you don't have "job" yet).  If you do bad, they'll re-train you and put you in the stand-by driver position (forgot the term),  (basically your a floater and have no route to call your own).
C.  Awesome soft skills (conflict-management, customer service, etc)
cons:
A.  Good luck in advancement.  Not saying it's impossible, but the beating your body is going to take for you to actually move up in a management position is going to take it's toll tie that in with the current management staying in the position FOREVER, leaves you no room to advance in the short term.
B.  Training (once you make it) is joke, but your made to go on the weekends anyways (just deal with it).
C.  Now the single most issue and extremely important you pay attention:  PAY SUCKS  Your paid off of 17 different variables + base pay.  Your base pay will cover gas and food for the week; but depends on your route volume, your only paid 2% on it up to 10k then it falls below that... you'll find out just how crappy the pay is if you accept lol 
D.  Promotions.  OMG the F'ing promotions they push on you to push sales (which they will try to convince you THAT'S where you'll make your money, and they are right.... if your a crook).

review_title: Enjoyed my job a lot and was sad to leave
pros: As a route  Driver you have the freedom to make your own decisions, work at your own pace and build great lasting relationships with your customers.
cons: There is  really not enough time in the day to meet all of your sales requirements, complete all your stops as well as address all the customer needs in a professional manner

review_title: A disciplined, career-focused professional can go far here, but will need to give something up too.
pros: Sales training is some of the best in the industry, and successful salespeople are richly rewarded.  Military-friendly employer.  Lots of opportunity if you are a "company man" and willing to be flexible in relocating.  Employee incentive and retirement plans are strong.  Work is hard, but pay is fair.
cons: As with many large companies, Cintas is policy-driven and can be ruthless its enforcement of those policies, which can pose a problem if personal issues come into conflict with professional responsibilities.  Cintas expects that you will put the company first, and a position at Cintas practically demands that you will sacrifice more of your quality of life and time at home than you would at another employer.  For the career-driven and disciplined professional, this may not necessarily be a bad thing, and the "Spartan" corporate culture may appeal to some, but it takes a very specific type of person to succeed at Cintas.  At Corporate lectures and trainings, corporate management openly admits to sacrificing personal relationships and quality of home life in favor of work, somewhat proudly, even.  Rather than adapting to changing employment practices and working conditions, Cintas prefers to write off the employees it has burned out as "not a culture fit."  Work above and beyond your normal scope may not be recognized or rewarded, as it is broadly an expectation that you will go above and beyond.

pros:
-You can get sales experience without the pressure of outside sales. Which also means you can coast and still make good money even if you’re not motivated or if you just have the employee mindset. I stand out at my location but if others put forth even a little more effort they would do better financially and career wise.

-Great benefits / good pay depending on your route 

-in my case never work a weekend 

-if you’re a lifer, the company will take care of you retirement wise. Good 401k matching and profit sharing. As far as Fortune 500 companies go, Cintas is probably in the upper echelon of caring for their employees.
cons:
-cyclical, roller coaster of emotion. Whether you have a great month or a poor month you’ll never get away from the “GO GO GO” of this job. You had a great month? Fantastic! Now go do even better! You had a bad month? Your pay may suffer. 

-I want to be careful when I say it so take it with a grain of salt, but there is a lot of hypocrisy in the mission statement compared to the actual execution of the job. For example, always do what’s best for the customer. Sure, but if you need to hit your numbers, things tend to get a little gray. I’ve been encouraged to take steps that I don’t feel are ethical to hit my numbers, and the customers and not getting the best service many times. Obviously, no matter what you’re encouraged to do it’s up to you to do the right thing. But my measured performance has suffered before by not doing things that I feel are not best for the customer. You WILL experience this, as it happens at all locations. Cintas is publicly traded so growth is expected constantly. I believe the FAS division is largely inflated at this point. 

-higher than normal turnover. In my experience the hiring process is more reactive than proactive. And when your managers hire people that they refer (and get referral bonuses on btw) it raises a few eyebrows. Or at least it should.

job_title: Management Trainee Program in Tampa, FL
pros:
-You quickly learn about how the company functions a whole
-Large company with heavy growth and advancement.
-Decent pay and great benefits
cons:
-Definition of drink the koolaid
-Super cheesy office atmosphere
-They tell you that you won't work more than 50 hours but once you're in they'll work you to 60-70 hours regularly with no overtime compensation. 80% of the work you do is mindless and involves physical labor. They have no concerns for when you start getting muscle pulls.
-If you don't kiss the butt of the GM they will start micromanaging you and get in your head to the point where you're constantly paranoid that you are doing something wrong. 
-HR comes across as someone to help, but ends up taking everything you say and becoming a tattle-tail (to a point where it becomes childish). 
-Tiny mistakes equal discipline sessions where they make you feel like you're screwing everything up when the reality is that it's not a big deal (even after a 12 hour day of hard work).
-THE LARGEST CON: You can see it in the long term employee's eyes that they've sold their souls. They all walk around smiling saying that they love their jobs. But when you get one-on-one with them all they do is talk about how they wish they could've had a better life.
-Tell all their employees "this is the best job ever" when in reality they could make a lot more with the effort they put in somewhere else

review_title: Great people, not a great company.
pros:
-They hire great front-line partners, management trainees, and Mid-level managers that were a pleasure to work with
-Great medical benefits, especially for those who have families.
-Overall, Cintas has a great Management Trainee program that has produced many great managers that were a pleasure to work for.
-It's a good opportunity to work at Cintas for people who may not have many opportunities or much experience, great resume builder.
-They obtain most of the market share in their industry, so its a very secure and stable company to work for.
cons:
-Absolutely no work/life back whatsoever.
-Constantly understaffed with no urgency from management to fix their staffing issues.
-Supervisors and in some cases MTs have to cover open routes 3-5 days a week on top off having their own work to do, resulting in a minimum 12 hour workday.
- Front-line plant partners and Service Sales Reps (SSRs) do not get paid nearly enough for all they are asked to do on a daily basis.
-Routes generally in my experience, were always overloaded with too many customer stops which would negatively affect how SSRs were paid due to commission structure of their "pay plan."
-Overall, due to the lack of financial compensation for the front-line partners and the workload they're given on a weekly basis, the "Corporate Culture" that Cintas' claims it has is disingenuous.

pros: Cintas offers a very competitive pay for sales and the industry. It really feels like a family when you work there. Everyone knows the company name which makes it easier to sell.
cons: Integrity is the reason I left this company. The norm here is to do whatever it takes, even if it’s not in the best interest of the customer, to make the sale. People on my team were constantly adding products to customers accounts they didn’t want or need to make sure they hit their number. It wasn’t  just selling where people had questionable morals but in the office too. Every quarter we would have sales contests. Part of your number was self reported of how many cold calls, dials, appointments ect you made. I remember during one contest someone self reported making 24 appointments during a 4 hour phone block. The worst part about all this is management sees it and doesn’t step in. The way the sales team is set up does not incentivize the rep to take care of the customer. Sales and ops continue to have a poor relationship and don’t work together. Another thing that bothered me what quota. We didn’t have a quota. The only way your success was truly measured was if you had a “presidents club” week. I constantly felt like I wasn’t good enough and didn’t feel like my smaller milestones were recognized. It doesn’t matter what time of year or why area you live in, presidents club is the same number for everyone. Yep, that’s right, a rep in NYC has the same number to hit for PC as a rep in Louisiana. Yes Cintas has a well structured training program. Unfortunately the material is outdated and reps don’t tend to use or apply training. For example Cintas really likes to promote telemarketing but all they do is hand you some phone scripts and have you memorize them.

job_title: First Aid & Safety Service Sales Representative in Paramount, CA
pros: The Partners and the benefits are amazing.   Nice work culture and everyone who is a rep helps out the other reps - even if they are on another team
cons: Not many opportunities for career advancement.  Managers were brought in from the outside,  and  knew nothing about the business, were managing partners with 20+ years of experience.

review_title: Good company to start your career but not a place to build a career. Horrible off-boarding
pros: Cintas has great benefits, they hire a lot of new grads and (now) pay them a really good starting salary.  Cintas is a growing company and investing into their stock will give you crazy good 401k money. They have a diverse customer base and really do have a great product at a premier, but worth it, price. It can be very rewarding when you win, and frontline partners (sales reps, service reps, etc) really have no limit to how much they can make. Up until my last day at Cintas I would have recommended.
cons: Being in management is VERY tough, long hours (10 hour minimum days), and you really have to do any and everything for your partners. There isn't a lot of support for managers on the HR side of things in getting new hires going or anything so you have to set it all up yourself. A new partner comes on and all the sudden your working 60-70 hours a week just to keep afloat. Your new partner won't get professional training until 6 months in so you have to train them until then, Cintas doesn't want to pay to send them to a conference if they aren't in it for awhile. Upper Management is out of touch, in my business specifically they raise projections 20-30% per year, no staff increases or anything they just expect you to "get there". I left Cintas for a higher paying position, put in my notice appropriately and worked a few days of it. My last day was terrible, they told me at 4pm as I was leaving for the day that today was my last day and I had to pack my things and leave, I didn't get to say goodbye to anyone and I worked there for almost 4 years. I later learned from a person at another location that my leaving at 4pm made my GM upset and that's when he decided to discontinue my 2 weeks, ridiculous that someone at another location would be privy to this much info. They sent my exit interview out the day I left and my previous boss TEXTED me to tell me that I should have been nicer on the review. Your benefits end the night you leave, even though you'll still be paying them in your last two weeks check they promise you they'll pay right away. Because I was on a car package that ends at midnight too so I had to try and find car insurance at 6pm when I got home just so I could drive the next day, not very easy. When I had a partner put in notice I ensured he was paid within 3 days of leaving Cintas but I had to email and call 5-6 times and eventually take it up to my Regional and HR Regional just to actually get my two weeks check paid to me and then had to fight over it being the correct amount to finally get paid. It took almost 3 weeks for me to get paid the actual amount I was owed. Lastly, I got COBRA for the month between my new job's insurance starting and it was over $200 more than what it initially said I would have to pay for it. If you're applying for a frontline role, go for it and it'll be great. If you're looking for a place to start a career or build a career and get some numbers under your belt, this is a good spot. If you're trying to build a career, work your way up the ladder, or have success in management be prepared to work 60-70 hrs in mid management, close to 90 in upper, and get ready to relocate on small dollars (they gave me $1k) to make that happen. It's just not worth it.

review_title: Excellent company... depending on your location
pros: You learn a lot about the industry and in any role become an expert at what the company does, safety, and hard work. The benefits are excellent, great 401k match. The company is constantly growing which makes for job security for everyone. After leaving this company and going to another big company I have come to realize they are a very organized company and are excellent at communicating large changes within the organization. They have now gotten more up to date with their technology and are constantly getting new products to keep them at the top of the industry. SSR's make great money, they are in charge of their own route so they can up sell and are eligible for monthly and quarterly bonuses.
cons: I worked in several different management positions while there and there is not a lot of work life balance. They always give you a hard time about taking vacation and expect you to live and breathe Cintas. If you are trying to start a family or enjoy working 9-5, M-F management at this company is not for you. The benefits may be great, but the pay is not. They don't often negotiate pay and will start you off low. You generally get a 3% raise a year which is about $.25 an hour to basically anyone. Also, if you are an SSR they are always short Partners because it is a demanding job and the hours can be long. That being said, if they are short staffed they give everyone a hard time about taking vacation or calling in sick. You have to request your time a year in advance and can only take 1 week M-F.

review_title: Big money and even bigger problems
job_title: Market Development Representative in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Fantastic Benefits, Car Package, Upwards of $100,000.00 per year with the potential to break 150k or more. If you enjoy the maximum amount of pressure, bordering on unreasonable, you may enjoy this.
cons:
I will organize this cons list into a few sections, and will do my best to remain as UN-biased as possible. 
Everything I will speak on is applicable only to the Market Development Representative position itself and is not indicative of any other sales position. Furthermore the operational aspects are only applicable to the CO Springs location in Colorado, and the region it is operating in. 

Responsibilities, Requirements and Expectations. 


The Position of Market Development Representative or MDR, has dramatically changed from when it was first conceived not so many years ago. In sharp contrast to the simple title of the Outside Sales Position (Facilities and Uniform Sales) which has seen minimal increases to the required number, the MDR position has seen sharp increases in it's quarterly and annual goals. 

President's Club Requirements
You are heavily encouraged to get to PC (President's Club) by the years end to be considered an exceptional rep, and PC nets you a nice little vacation along with some company stocks as well. The number is closely monitored and to ensure that only 5% of all reps nationwide are able to go and is increased sometimes yearly if more than this number attain it. (You are also not likely to be considered for a promotion unless you go to PC a few times as well.) The Goal is very high, and very lofty and raises every single year. You are expected to compete with markets in California and Nevada where prices are generally expected to be higher and opportunities are much more abundant. This is not measured, modified, handicapped or accounted for in anyway. A new requirement released this year requires 100 current customer account renewals which makes things even more difficult due to the terrible retention this region currently suffers from, I will discuss this in the Service Agreement Renewals and Operation Section. 

Commission and Pay Structure
In addition to the grind of hitting the PC number required (This year is 24,500 in 2020), you must also deal with the convoluted and confusing pay structure, along with aggressive monthly audits that are likewise confusing in there application, I will discuss them briefly below. In addition to this, the omission structure of the MDR changes yearly and is seemingly based upon whatever the company wants you to sell at that moment in time. Last Year we were given 5:1 Multipliers on everything Sold with the exception of Linen and Paper (Which is always 1:1), This year, corporate raised the Uniform Multiplier to 6:1, but dropped everything else down a notch to 4:1. I see this as a con because these adjustments are the lowest multipliers we have seen yet in sum total. In contrast the Outside Sales Positions have had there multipliers and incentives increased yearly, with the largest increase being to now have the capability to make money at a 9:1 ratio on selling Uniform Insurance. They stripped the MDR position the ability to sell Insurance at the same time without explanation.(It was later reintroduced at a 1:1 ratio requiring additionally a 60 month term agreement as mandatory to be paid) To sum all of this up, your multipliers are decreased significantly on any sale with a Service Agreement that is 48 months or fewer (4 years or fewer) in term and further reduced further down to 1:1 if the account is Nationally owned.

Monthly Audits
Your omissions are audited monthly under the pretense that the product you sold bills out for 4 weeks. If an Delivery Driver (SSR) has to credit the product for one week due to a shortage you will completely be denied the sale 4 months later. Other parts of the audit are completely unexplained, such as additional uniforms to current customer. If that same customer stops any other uniform on the account, not pertaining to your sell, but maybe an employee was let go and his uniforms were returned, you will be docked upwards of 60% of the total sell for a 'volume' decrease, that had nothing to do with the original 

Bonus Potential
This is the hardest section of all to write for me personally, and most certainly the toughest to be unbiased on, so please bear with me as I attempt to list the facts despite my feelings about them.
You have the potential to bonus at the following ratios once per quarter,
1:1 About what you will get payed if you exceed your quarterly goal. 
1:5:1
2:1 – Middle Tier Payout
4:1
5:1 Highest payout Tier
Here's the kicker though, you must account for only 'eligible volume' sold.
