You can sell upwards of 4500+ per quarter to achieve your summit club number, and totally fall flat of a bonus by having most of that volume disqualified. You will receive no credit for linen products and paper has a an annual hardliner that accounts for maybe 5% of your total allowable number. 

Worst yet, and this is probably the most corrupt, twisted and disgusting part of it all, is that if you work your butt-off for a large customer like say, a hospital and sell 2 quarters worth of volume all by yourself, your pay will be capped 40% for the year, and every bit of whatever else you sold will go to a Major Account Manager you've never even spoken to. MD's are encouraged to work with there Major Account Managers, and were told in the past that MA's will be there key to PC, this year however Md Rs have been capped at $2000 per MAM and most the Mams will never actually sell anything for you. Normally you'll sell the account, the MAM will flag the account as theirs automatically diminishing your omissions and take 60% of the pay and volume for themselves without even communicating with you. My associate who also shares my roll found out when his bonus tiers dropped from 5:1 down to 2:1 because a MAM he had never even met flagged the account as sold. This is incontestable as well

Finally this company promises uncapped omissions, but will absolutely cap you at $5000 on any one account, and $2000 in bonus eligibility on any major account. You will literally make no money, and receive no credit towards any bonus or omission check. The one silver lining is that you will continue to receive volume credit towards P.C..



Service Agreement Renewals
The latest hat they've asked us to wear recently comes in the form a new stipulation to achieve PC, that being the requirement of attaining 100, 60-Month+ Service Renewals (or contracts with an out) in addition to the already lofty monetary goal. It makes sense that they would do this as many locations in our region alone (California, New Mexico, Arizona, Colorado, Nevada) were already suffering from a low retention rate even before the pandemic, which has only exacerbated the issue. In an announcement made by the SVP of service, Md Rs were asked to work with Service Managers in an aggressive campaign to attain a maximum amount of renewals in the shortest amount of time. The most Topsy turnover part of all of it is that MD's don't report or work for service, but were being required to take part in the campaign. The problem lies with that fact that most Md Rs aren't going to President's Club (5% always) thus this specific requirement doesn't apply to them but they are still pushed to be a part of renewing accounts regardless. I will cover this more in the next section. 

OPERATIONS
This section mostly pertain to my specific region (Mountain Group, Colorado, Arizona, Nevada, California, New Mexico) and my specific location LOC 562, when noted. 
Currently in the above listed region, the Mountain Region as it's deemed, we are suffering adversely from poor customer retention on the operations side, but doing very well on the sales side. The problem as myself, and most of my peers see it is that service is very poor for the high price that Cintas asks for. I can't tell you how many accounts I've visited in a week, located cities apart on different routes all have the same complaints. These are all throughout my territory of CO Springs, Pueblo, La Junta, Trinidad, Ramon, Buchanan Vista, Saliva and Canon City, and concern the distribution of products from Denver, Greeley and sometimes further to LOC562 on Co Springs. These are some of the objections to selling concerning bad service that I walk into on a weekly basis.

Uniforms are consistently lost, delivered and sometimes don't show up at all, with little to no communication about a solution for weeks to months. 

Service Managers rarely visit the accounts that have issues, most customers have no idea who there account manager is. Service managers do not answer there phones, and rarely answer emails. 

Price increases aren't communicated, and sometimes there are multiple in a year. 

New product launches are always mismanaged. Sales is encouraged to massively over-promote and push customers on a new product, but that new product is consistently in short supply or severely back ordered leading to massive credits and service issues. 

These issues have gone on for years now. I state this to warn anyone interested in this position that once you sell a product, the service team will often fail to maintain that service via the avenues above. Since you are limited to almost exclusively inside sales, you will need to put our fires all over the the place to ensure you can continue to sell. The larger the customer, the larger the mismanagement in almost every case. There isn't a solution in site at the moment nor has there been in my tenure here. I've personally watched large customers just walk away with the only attempt made to save them being made as after both feet were out the door. Reactive and consistently not proactive seems to the module at Cintas. 

To conclude, please please please read all of that one more time, and deeply consider a move to Cintas at this location, or in this region. I am currently looking for another job being at the end of my sanity rope here. I made nearly 100k my second year in this job but you couldn't pay me any amount of money to put up with the constant problems, political agenda and inefficiencies that Cintas Uniform Rental in Colorado Springs currently has, and consistently undermines your attempts to be successful.

review_title: Great opportunity as long as you don't need a personal life.
pros: Room for growth if you perform.  Solid, profitable company which means job security if you can meet the very high performance standards.  Lots of performance reviews, both formal and informal so no secrets in terms of how you are doing.
cons: Little concern for helping employees find a work/life balance.  Little flexibility for time off.  Vacation policy is sad.  Be prepared to work, work, work.

review_title: Its ok, its a job. Would not want my children to work here.
pros: Descent medical benefits and vacation policy.
cons: Sales reps oversell to customers to increase commission and credit, customers then drop product and it hits the service team. No deduction in sales compensation. Invoices very confusing to customers. Everything is a rental item when some products should be a direct sale.

pros: It is a full time job (ie, steady employment), and the health benefits (medical, dental, eye) are pretty good.
cons: There is no consideration that you may have a life outside of Cintas. All managers and supervisors are expected to work 60+ hour weeks (including some weekends), and the lower level employees are constantly being called at home to change their schedules around. The pay is lower than average for similar jobs. Cintas is also a very beaurocratic company. Also, the drivers (SSRs) and plant employees are forced to dig through disgusting, week-old towels that contain rotten food, vomit, etc.

pros: Great experience in multiple departments.   Cintas takes a lot of pride in meticulous hiring.  They make sure everyone they hire is a good culture fit.  Employees are all friendly and looking out for your best interest.  Everything you learn, whether its in customer service, production, office, service, HR,  you can take what you learn and utilize the information in your future career.
cons: Depending on your rotation, you can work a lot of hours.   But again, the more you work the more experience you get.  Endless amount of knowledge to learn.

review_title: Local Management doesn't live up to Cintas policies.
pros: Use company work truck, able to finish daily duties in reasonable time, and work 4 days a week. Most employees will help with on the job training.
cons: Local management do not treat employees fairly or use same ruler when administering discipline. Management rush to conclusions before examining all the facts of a situation. They retaliate on the employee if they whistle-blow. They are not completely accommodating when an injured employee needs to see the doctor and without thought terminate employees that have existing workers comp injuries.

review_title: If you like to sell this is the place for you
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Madison, WI
pros: Fast paced environment where you get to work with minimal supervision while on route.  Four day work week. Pretty flexible if you have things going on in your personal life. Management does a fantastic job of helping you if you have proven your worth.
cons: Multiple 12 hour days, you are forced to stay at work for sales meetings, sell, sell, sell attitude. Relationship between sales team and service reps is rocky at best.

pros: Everyone was friendly, everyone there were team players,  the company provided uniforms, weekly pay plus incentive pay,great benefits , 40 hours a week, the company were about helping  their employees
cons: The only down fall I would say is the company pay you based off production. Which means depending on how many garments you send out in that week ,if you don't reach the same number or higher every week pay goes down.

job_title: Facility Service Sales Professional in Winterthur
pros: Cintas is not only an employer, but a home for me. Everyday, I talk to a partner, I feel like I'm talking to famiily. We are depended on by so many types of industries and have had 38 years of un-interuppted growth! How awesome is that for business and for ourselves? I started with Cintas as an intern my senior year of college, and Cintas has became my true passion due to the experience I have received an the overall quality management that has helped to form me by teaching me and building the skills I had already acquired. Someone would be crazy not to join Cintas. Cintas is an OPPORTUNITY, and I work for the best CORPORATION in the world. People may say as posted earlier, Cintas is cheap, blah blah, but you know what, we are SPARTAN, and we concentrate on acting with competitive urgency for our customers rathar than exceeding funds for trips and gifts for those that we can simply make so happy by providing them our convenient and excellent product and service. That's what Cintas is about. They take care of their partners 110% and it's obvious that we have been succeeding this long for all the right reasons :)
cons: I do not have any con's, but advice would be that at Cintas, it can be very time consuming because our goal is to act with competitive urgency with everything. You have to be able to have excellent time management skills so that you can seperate the difference and have a work and life balance. This will make you happy with your career and life.

review_title: Promised the world, delivered much less.
pros:
-Decent starting salary
-Benefits effective sooner than most positions
-Corporate credit card for gas
-Weekly paycheck
-Flexible hours, not a lot of in-office time
cons:
-Management is a 'good 'ol boys club' so it is nearly impossible to out someone who is a manager, no matter how incompetent they are

-Unfounded favoritism, directed toward sales reps who kiss the most butt. Management encourages brown-nosing and directs favoritism toward reps that are well below their sales quota, as long as they continue to kiss up.

-2 words: UNORGANIZED SYSTEMS! Most of the departments do not work well together, almost 100% of the time it feels like we're fighting an internal battle against our own team and co-workers. A lot of issues fall back onto the sales department because other departments do not want to take responsiblity for their own shortcomings. It seems like the motto is 'salespeople make the most money so they should eat the most crap'.

- Micromanagement is OUT. OF. CONTROL.
During my interview process, I answered a question about why I left a previous position with the answer  "I made my quota every month for 3 consecutive years, but continued to be micromanaged, which is extremely frustrating and time consuming". The interviewer proceeded to tell me that if I accepted the position with Cintas, I would not be faced with the same issue. This was a bold faced lie. I continue to make my quota week after week and am micromanaged as if I am a total slacker. EXTREMELY frustrating.

-Too much 'pass the buck'.
It is never anyones fault that something happened, or that their job wasn't done properly, it is always someone elses fault. This never ceases to amaze me, despite hearing this whiny fingerpointing excuse day after day, week after week.

-If you speak out about any of the above, your hand is slapped for being 'negative' even though it is actually being REALISTIC.

-Management partners sit in their office all day managing the ridiculous amount of reporting salespeople spend half of their week turning in, then when your manager does come on a sales call they are completely cocky and worthless.

review_title: Good to get your feet wet, but then move on.
pros: Great insurance, well known company to put on your resume, good as an entry level sales position, independence and freedom throughout the day.
cons: Compensation could be better, as soon as you grow your route to where you make money management will split it. Vacation can be hard to get off. A service position so there is a lot of physical work involved at times. Good for a few years, but not many advance.

review_title: Driver Do it ALL!!!! and more?
pros: Good pay and if you know how to sell you will make so money.
cons: plant (people that load trucks and order product) don't care. Drivers do it all. You are out on road all day in heat, rain, and weather. if you are fast a  person you will go far but OT sucks. I have fun on route but when get back to office it brings me down.

review_title: Don't Expect Respect, Expect Overwork and Condescension
job_title: Service Representative in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Decent health and 401k benefits. 4 day work week for drivers, weekends off for all. Decent low level co-workers (good people in a bad company.)
cons: No accountibility for managers. They sidestep all responsibility and throw the regular workers under the bus at every opportunity. Slow to hire replacements, or just plain don't, spreading more work to already overworked people. Claim that they have a culture of openess, but will shut you down if you have anything even slightly negative to say, even if it's about them not following their own policies. They want silent worker drones, and nothing else. No degree? You'll never see a management position! Raises are at a maximum of 3% per year, and only brown-nosers will ever get that. I worked there 14 years in 4 different departments, and went once for a 6 year span with no review or raise. Every time I brought it up, I was brushed aside. Once had a general manager tell me that I would NEVER get another raise, because I was "overpaid as it is."  Every year I worked there, I heard "Just be glad you've got a job in THIS economy!" Even in the boom of the late 90's. Once heard the HR manager say of an employee that said he was overworked, "He can either quit, or shut up and go back to work!" She said this rather loudly in front of an office full of hourly employees. Not very professional. Also one of the many employers that decided to tell you how to vote in 2012, implying that if the election didn't go their way, you could lose your job, or at least your health insurance. And that's how they rule; with a culture of intimidation.

review_title: Lots of bureaucracy at all levels
pros: Good job for those with no college education, or those who are from the military. Benefits & medical are not bad, but you still have to pay around $100 a month.
cons: No upward opportunities. They hire from without rather than promoting from within. Poor upper management from District Managers up to VP, who are all clueless and care only about numbers. There is always the blame game. There is also no accountability from senior management who don't want to spend money to hire trained maintenance workers but instead expect service partners (drivers and forklift drivers) to perform maintenance work on all machinery without any training. And when the machines break, the blame will be on the service partners or location managers, who will be disciplined or terminated. A solution to the problems are never provided, so the problems reoccur often, again with no real solution. The pay is about 70% of market rate, enough to keep you there, but too little for the work you provide. There are lots of closed doors and secrecy. Human Resources are there to help the company terminate partners without getting sued. Human Resources are not there to help the partners. Human Resources are never around unless they are trying to terminate a partner, then 3 HR personnel appear. Everyone is overworked. Overtime is mandatory for all partners; i.e. very bad work-life balance. Salary partners can not take vacation because the company do not have enough staff to handle the responsibilities when they take vacation. Those who try to take vacation will be asked to wait and also the work will have to be made up when they get back; you will have to work 16 hour days to complete everything after your vacation. No raises for 5 years. Work safety injuries are covered up to help the bottom line; i.e. put a band-aid on it. Plenty of auditors who come and point fingers but offer no help or solutions then leaves immediately; this happens every month. Cintas culture is just a gimmick to make you feel you are wrong if you don't believe or follow their ideology that your hard work and the company's cheapness will ultimately benefit everyone. The fact is, it only benefits the shareholders especially Mr. Farmer, who have stock options. The values they project are good on paper only, as no one in senior management follow what they preach. Don't complain or they will terminate you expeditiously. Nothing here ever changes for the better.

pros: Ability to be on route by yourself
cons: I worked as an SSR in the First Aid and Safety division. You work long hours, no opportunities for growth and management is awful. You are micromanaged to the point that they put a device on your van to track your every move. On average you will make about $300 per week (without commission) and with commission you could make about 40-45k if you work 10 hour days. I was nationally ranked as top 5 in performance and still only made that much.  Raises do not exist so don't get your hopes up. I left after 1.5 years and that was the best decision I've ever made.

review_title: Amazing Opportunity - for those who want it
pros: Cintas has phenomenal leadership, full of opportunity. You will get world-class training from a world class organization, be compensated well, and be enabled to always add value. you have direct access to the leadership team who are always receptive to new ideas and feedback. This company is very well managed financially and operationally.
cons: Growth can be slow because of the old school mentality that exists in some tenured members.

review_title: What you put in? It's what you get!
job_title: Facility Services Sales Representative in Sacramento, CA
pros: Comp Plan - Good People - Great Training - They make a huge investment into their Salespeople. Aggressive growth!    True upward mobility for the person who can bust their butt
cons: Too much administrative work to contract customers. Delivery of customer goods can take as long as 3 weeks. Depending on operations and service, it can lag sometimes.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Good company to work for. There is opportunity to move up as long as you do a good job. Friendly enviorment and at least at my location managers and supervisors care for you. Good co-workers. 4 day work week good if you want to keep studying have family etc.
cons: A lot of up and downs loosing accounts, it affects youre pay. Departments change personel and managment consistently. Can have a academic degree and it is over looked  and has little or no value. Have to fight hard to go up and be very persistent. Not the most glamorous of jobs.

pros: Paid weekly.
cons: Cintas culture used to be about doing the right thing for employees and customers.  That is no longer the case.  It’s about what’s good for shareholders and squeezing every ounce of revenue from customers no matter the path taken.  Out of touch management on all levels.  Used to be a 5 star job.  Not anymore.   Some partners have small routes and are done by 11 am why others work double the volume and double the hours and no relief is given.

review_title: Smoke and Mirrors - Get Hired as a Sales Rep, Only to Stay an SSR
pros: If you have a good route as an SSR you can literally work 5 hours a day and pull $50k/year. At least in our location some managers do not micromanage - some do. If you perform no one will ever be on your back. Some people at my location were earning $50k+ and getting home before 11am each day.... so it's a totally easy and brainless job which you can actually make decent money at with a work life balance. But that's only for people who get a good route. Plenty of SSRs in my location are right at the $35k mark.
cons:
Be warned - lots of lies and smoke blown in your face. They post Sales Reps job openings, make you come in for 4-6 interviews, then tell you they need you to be on route as an SSR for 4 months as "training".  SSR BASE PAY IS ONLY $16,000/YEAR. They will tell you there is a $35,000 base but that is not a base, that is a guarantee - so if you fall below that they will bring you at least up to that. Sales reps get a $43k base plus car package which brings you to $48k, though they advertise $50k base and in my opinion a car package should not be included in base pay listings so it's a bit confusing.

Once you're hired as a sales rep and put on SSR route for "4 months training" you will find yourself 10+ months later still on route as an SSR with no end in sight on when you will actually be moved to the sales rep role. Starting around month four you will be told weekly by a manager how soon you're getting into the sales team, and how there are whispers around the office of moving you in there.  It gives you a false sense of hope until you fully realize it's all a lie and they are keeping you motivated to get as much out of you as they can and to keep you making money on route. I know for a fact they have hired four SSR's after me using the Sales Rep posting but convincing them to do SSR for a few short months.

So if you find yourself hired as a sales rep and put as an SSR for a few months of training, definitely don't turn your route into one of the top ones or grow it too much - you will never be moved into your position.

Another note:
The lack of women in any type of management position is also shocking. I had an issue with repetitive feminine infections due to the non-breathability of uniform pants and I specifically stated I didn't feel comfortable speaking to any male managers. I was told by HR that the process included having to speak to the managers at my location. I brought it up in a very professional manner using medical terminology and the response from the male manager was, "how sweaty do you get down there?!" From then on I lost all trust in management and realized Cintas is exactly what all the other 2,000+ reviews say - a good boys club.

job_title: Facility Services Sales Representative in Columbus, OH
pros:
Cintas is a huge company with formidable, clean buildings with many employees.  

The employees are generally friendly and helpful.

There are restrooms you can use.

A wide variety of products and services.

The Cintas brand is well-known.

You can make six figures.

There is paid time off, and insurance.

There is some flexibility in your schedule.
cons:
New businesses sales rep is not a job, it's not a career - it is a way of life.  You will need to work 50 - 100 hours a week if you are going to succeed.  You will have to clean up, and follow up, where Cintas has operational short-comings.  So you can sell all week, but that doesn't mean Cintas will get the products and services to customers - so you will often have to do it out of your personal vehicle, before or after hours, or on the weekends.  Otherwise, it won't always get done.  Your customers will be angry and want to cancel service which means your commission has to be paid back.

Training is focused 90% on call scripts (this job is cold-calling from a cubicle).  Very little training is on products or the pricing, so you have to figure that our yourself.

The #1 priority is Phone Block which means you are forced to make cold calls from a cubicle even if your customers are calling you with problems.  Management does not care, even though you are required to read a book titled, "The Sprit is the difference" where it lists Cintas principle objective is to, "exceed customer expectations."  That is not true.  Phone block, and new business is their priority - PROFIT - not customer service.


Moreover, during Phone Block you are supposed to get 10 new appointments in that four hours - which no one can do.  Most people you call transfer you voicemail, or tell you the decision-maker is unavailable.  It's out of date tactics, and prospects get hammered all day long by other marketers selling: gas, electric, you name it.  You are assigned a mentor who will even tell you to, "Inflate your numbers" because no one meets the requirement.  There is tons of lying and exaggerating that go on.

You territory is tiny.

Very churn and burn.  They constantly are hiring new sales reps because most quit in less than 36 months.

Turnover is extremely high with the average sales rep only with the company 3 years, at most, before resigning.  It is even shorter for the drivers who get burned out by the workload, long hours, and low pay.  So your customers have constantly changing drivers who don't know their location, who is who, or what products they are supposed to get.

The software applications are cheap and extremely slow.  This means more time you must spend (outside of normal work hours) waiting on the slow system, and IT rarely can fix anything.  

Cintas pricing is significantly higher than the competition which makes taking customers from competitors extremely difficult.

The VPs arbitrarily raise the "minimum" to say $50.00/stop which means competitors who don't have that minimum can play that card against you.

Customers must sign a FIVE YEAR CONTRACT, which most people refuse to do.

The mentality is MORE, MORE, MORE and FASTER, FASTER, FASTER...  No matter how much you sell, you will hear something like, "I need double that."  Thankless, zero gratitude, or reward.

pros: Fantastic hard working people. Great company culture that is moral and urgent. Company is surprisingly quick to respond to threats and opportunities for how large it is.
cons: The company is too tight with money. This leads to many situations where they lose a dollar to save a penny. There is too much red tape in several areas. Company tries to be diverse but is mostly good old white males.

review_title: Very thorough experience. Delves into all aspects of management on the Uniform and FS side of the business.
pros: Cintas provided a diverse experience, with many opportunities for advancement if the necessary work was put in.
cons: There were a lot of red tape and seemingly excessive formalities, although I can't say this is uncommon amongst corporations of this size. At times it could be very HR sensitive, but overall it was a good place to work.

pros:
Ability to see all aspects of the business
Great training for someone who would like to manage people
Large company with a lot of different opportunities
cons:
If you are not a morning person this job might be difficult. 
If you do not like working long hours, this company is not for you. 
In the MT program, it is very difficult to see what other options there are outside of your location post graduation of the program. You have to do a lot of research on your own to find something you like within Cintas.

pros: Great training, people and experience. There is a mentorship program which is great, but make sure you utilize it completely. Your mentors become your cheerleaders
cons: Favouritism. Do Nothing Nancy's. This is why I left. Too much gossiping, people that don't do their own work and when they don't, you can guarantee it will affect your worklife.

job_title: Service Sales Representative in Hattiesburg, MS
pros: Set your own hours. Great benefits. Advancement opportunities if you are willing to move. Management team at my location is very supportive.
cons: Working in the condition. Managers pass the buck when times get tough with customers. Typical corporate rah rah BS.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Pinellas Park, FL
pros:
Cintas really is the industry leader and continuously re-invests back into the business with progressive product improvement and innovation. I find security knowing Cintas is financially stable, secure and a growing company. The company jungle gym of opportunity is exciting and presents continuous professional challenges. I have found the professional development Cintas has taught me, has translated into my personal life. 

I know that I have ample opportunities for development as either an independent contributor or leader for as bold as I choose to be.
cons: No job at Cintas is easy, however Cintas is a company that rewards performance and consistency over tenure...

pros:
Steady income 
Shift work is DuPont schedule ( 7 days off each month )
Coworkers are friendly and helpful
The actual loading work is fairly easy, not physically strenuous
cons:
Not much room to move up 
Hired as loader on shift work but they typically put you on wash rack which is straight days and much harder work. They won't tell you this until you show up for your first day of work. 
The PVC powder gets EVERYWHERE constantly breathing it in even if you wear a dust mask 
Other places are paying up too two dollars more an hour doing the exact same thing through the Sam company

pros: The benefits package is excellent. The only issue was with poor dental benefits and that was fixed just before I left. The location I worked at had awesome people. The management really did care about and appreciate the work you did. Everyone was really awesome about trying their best to take care of you. Pay was decent but not stellar. 4 day work week.
cons: This job is tough. Your back will hurt. Your shoulders will be shot and your legs and feet will be killing you. But man will you be in shape! Also, how hard you work doesn’t necessarily mean the more money you make. So many factors are involved in your paycheck and bonuses, many of which are beyond your control. If you have a few businesses not paying their bills then poof! There goes $500/month. If you work deliver to one company and they aren’t paying then you’re stopping there for free. It’s a bit of a scheme in how your bonuses work. Finally, the meeting. Oh. My. God. The freaking meetings! Every week, at least one, often more starting at 5:00am which delays your day by a half hour or 45 minutes. When you drive two hours to the areas your stops are in it is aggravating. Essentially when some people are done with their day by noon and you’re not back until 4:00-5:00 and they are making more money than you.

pros: Most of the people were awesome
cons: Getting threatened twice. Working with someone who shows porn at work to the granddaughters of coworkers. Same worker makes fun of the handicap janitor, makes racist comments, spreading rumors about affairs and a week later the lady quits, recruiting nude pics from female coworkers along with calling the pet names all day everyday. Getting DUI's 10-15 minutes before work and nothing happens. I could go on and on and management does nothing.

job_title: Service Sales Representative in Houston, TX
pros: This job is really great, and it has provided me with very good sales experience.  But they emphasize front line partners as the most important in the company.   You will learn a lot and build your confidence by working here.
cons: You will be brushed aside for Amazon, Northern, Grangier, Fastenal, Pig, as this digital age is growing, the need for educated safety professionals is dwindling, as many customers go online as opposed to the old school Cintas method.  Cintas is also behind the curve with many initiatives, such as water machines, complying and getting ahead with state laws that come out.  Often getting information to it's book of customers slower than what customers need.  Often times you will find yourself speaking to something that a potential client has already completed.  Such as training or buying items to remain in accordance to state laws.  They make ssr's feel important, yet make them feel powerless when it comes to negotiating and brokering deals while in the field.  Specifically with larger national account customers.

review_title: Tons of opportunity requires tons of dedication and hard work.
pros: There are several opportunities for advancement.  In fact more opportunity than people to fill the roles.  Managers at Cintas don't have a long life span.  Either they are burned out, fired or promoted.  Not many 10 year managers around.  If you want to grow with a company, move to different locations, or even countries, you will have the opportunity to do so with Cintas.  The people that work at Cintas are generally good people, especially the plant partners.  You will have a lot of fun with the plant partners.  The drivers are spoiled at times, but are very good at what the do.  A lot of GMs are out of touch or just don't get how to be successful.  Too many are promoted into that position before they are ready.  the other ones have the people skills of a Doberman Pincher.
cons: You won't have too much of a life initially.  If you are being hired into a position, that probably means there is a serious need for your services.  If there is a serious need for your services, don't expect to be able to come in and kick your feet up.  You will get your hands dirty at every level beneath GM.  It takes time to adjust to this coming out of school.  Cintas does not have many extra bodies, so be prepared to jump in and do the work of a subordinate from time to time.

pros:
Good training from the beginning and ongoing. 
highly recruited from by better compnaies.
SR Sales director is actually a very down to earth and smart  individual. 
It is a good starting point for a new college grad or someone from service to come over and make a better life.
cons:
TURNOVER!! My team turned over 5 times in 3 years. 

Unrealistic sales goals! Understand there are 10+ other competitors now and Cintas is NO DIFFERENT! Matter of fact Cintas has the worst product quality around. 

work/life balance is terrible. They make you feel bad for taking a vacation

MDR position is the biggest joke in the compnay! All they do is PAY the drivers for already completed CRF and they make more than outside reps and managers. They do not have to have the customer sign anything, so next delivery when 50 extra dollars in on the ivoice it hits the numbers., and most of the time immeditaly credited off, the MDR gets credit and paid and the driver gets hosed.  The MDR role is designed to cheat the compnay and customers out of money. They are by far the worst sales people in the company.  

SPARTAN = CHEAP ---- Cintas puts on a show like they care for their people but they do not show it. Everyone that has a sales force does a PC! It isnt that special

Phone Block = 8 hours of cucbicle work punding phones like "boiler room" ....... enough said! 

Sales ans Service hate each other in every location I have ever been to. The reality is that sales will do whatever they have to do to maximize the 1st invoice and screw service on every account. Service does not want new business because their pay gets degraded every year and it just takes more time and adds more stops to their already long day

FEAR-- CINTAS enjoys doing corporate visits to local locations. Not because they want to help, or see things in action but to have each location put on 5 hour long power point presentations on why they all need to keep their jobs.  The upper executives are the most arrogant people in the universe, starting at the CEO.

review_title: the salary do not meet the responsibility , to much turn over in the top management position
job_title: Service Sales Representative in Piscataway, NJ
pros: benefits are good,work life balance is good
cons:
THE COMPANY HAS VERY LITTLE MORALS THE CUSTOMER IS JUST A MONEY TREE, SERVICE IS NO LONGER IMPORTANT HOW MUCH MONEY THEY CAN SQUEEZE OUT THE CLIENT IS JOB 1.
I worked for Cintas for over 7 years as a SSR and had a different manager every year,and only 2 very small raises since my start of employment with them . The company's products do not match the cost of them but the company consistently make the SSR raise the cost on a monthly basis to the client which puts a lot of stress on doing the job.  The job changed from getting paid on a 90% service and 10% sales ratio to 95% sales and  5% service, to earn more money you must Increase your route volume an/or sales this was  mandatory. overall in my entire working career this was the worst place i ever worked it started out good but over the years changes made cause the job to be 100%different form when I started,one  example:starting salary was $50000.00 yr now its 30-40000.00 a year, as cost of living increase your income decrease, you get paid a small base and 3% commission on your route volume.IF YOU WANT TO BE APPRECIATED AND COMPENSATED FOR YOUR HARD WORK THEN  THIS IS NOT THE PLACE TO WORK.

review_title: The BEST company I ever worked for!
job_title: FS Sales Representative in Franklin, WI
pros: Hiring, interview, training, and sense of team is immediate. There is a ton of support, continued training, and benefits that remain the top of all companies I ever worked for.
cons: I was extremely saddened to have to quit Cintas because of the above. I left the FS-SSR position because of a decision to cut personel commision. I made a comfortable commison of nearly 18% of an over 6k a week route, but nearly a year after working there there was a devastating cut of over half my commision with additional work requirements on an already very demanding route. Requirements included adding money to the route or your position would be compromised, atop other individual account work that was not delegated properly. What was being asked needed to be done within human resources, and accounting personel. Also one aspect of the adds included fuel fees and such that most long term contract holders vehemently declined including refusal of service, though billing continued. As router personel, monies could be deducted at the point of sale, but these were then either added back or included in a different way later on per invoice. I found it difficult to keep accounts in good order or relations positive when making weekly, biweekly or monthly contact. The support from service managers wad always good, but the problem of profit demand was very bad when you consider your customer base and competition.

pros: Cintas is very much a policy driven company. It has great growth potential. Some divisions have a take home vehicle and very flexible hours.
cons: Must be able to drink the corporate kool-aid. Company has heavy patches of "good Ole boy network".  Cintas is not big on keeping people around that are making too much money or try to step out of the box.

pros: Great benefits.  Great opportunities to learn business basics.  The product sold is good, but not so critical that a mistake made is going to keep anyone up at night. Safety is important. Pretty good job security.
cons: Smaller locations are expected to meet the same expectations as big ones, with fewer people and less money.  Corporate is slow to change with the times; everything is old fashioned and not much is being done to make the business more appealing to millennials, good talent is hard to come by.

pros: The car package is wonderful.  If you get a good manager, which is one out of a billion, and I got that one, you will love your job and it will make sales easier and a fun pace to work at.
cons: Nobody is your friend, except your own kind.  Ex. I was a sales rep, and I can only trust a sales rep.  Cintas is not who itt ued to be 5 years ago.  Now everyone wants to leave and its a nightmare!  Don't APPLY!

review_title: My overall experience was not one that was very good.
job_title: Uniform Sales Representative in Chicago, IL
pros: The company was fairly understanding when it came to time off and work/family balancing.  The company has the name that helps you sell their product and is very well know in the industry.
cons: I found that advancement opportunities were very limited for a company of this size.  It was very difficult to get promoted to one of their different divisions.

review_title: a Micromanaging Blame-Game in which only the loyalist survive
pros:
This is a horrible place to work but is great to have on your resume.
Pay is competitive.
cons:
Stressful.  Incompetent managers, Dog-Eat-Dog mentality,  Management is only interested in placing blame, not fixing issues.  Good-ole-boys network of promoting buddies only.
No recognition for jobs well done - only reprimands for non compliance.
No empathy from managers.
No time off.
Gossip and back-biting are rampant.
Managers refuse to defend good ideas but readily condemn anyone suggesting change of any kind.
Atmosphere of fear and tension.

review_title: They laid off an entire department only to tell the employees they could be hired back through a temp agency
job_title: Document Imaging Specialist in Hazelwood, MO
pros: They were understanding when i needed to take off for personal reasons
cons: They do not value their employees.They put people in charge of departments when they have no clue what the department does.They prefer to use temp agencies or to outsource their work instead of keeping dedicated employees. They do not like to give raises.They work good employees to death and promise them raises and bonuses they never receive.

pros: Good knowledgeable people that is willing to work hard.  Managers that are willing to listen, and understand the difficulty of the roles.
cons: Poor long term planning, tend to make short term gain at the cost of long term benefits.  A lot of multi-level interference that cause some dissonance and confusions on the overall strategy.

review_title: Great Place To Work...But You Will Work
job_title: Former Administrative Assistant Promoted to Rental Program Manager in Mason, OH
pros: Professionalism, Ethics, very high standards. You have to be on your A game every day. If you excel, you will do well. They "walk the talk". Policies & Procedures are your guide but you must be familiar with them.
cons: Can be a little strict/rigid. Some managers don't buy into the work/life balance concept.

review_title: Tough Hours, Tough Culture, Some Good People
pros: The people, sure you get your bad eggs here and there but in general the people at Cintas are good people. If you work hard you can see your results pretty clearly, everything is tracked and monitored.
cons: Cintas will suck the life out of you, especially in the service manager role. You're expected to work from 6:30am until earliest 5pm, but the work load is so severe you're probably going to have to stay later. Micromanagement is the name of the game, everything you do will be scrutinized.

job_title: Uniform Attendant in San Diego, CA
pros: Benefits for full-time employees. It can boost a resume if you get moved around a bit between departments/jobs - otherwise give it a couple of years.
cons: Management, some of the jobs- not exactly something you can carry over to many jobs so don't stick with it too long.

pros: Flexible work schedule, Products are easy to understand, colleagues become close friends
cons: The pay is horrible, Management doesnt know what they are doing, The GM assigned to your location cares much more about the operations of the location rather than sales (huge annual bonus), locations cant keep up with sales demand thus no commission/claw back, you have to payoff your drivers to actually do a good job otherwise you will lose sales, the company is cheap and doesn't provide any perks

pros: Loved the people I work with. Great team atmosphere. PTO was okay. No ceiling on what you can make.
cons: Manager tried to micro manage, goals were way out of reach. cheap-but I guess you don't make billions spending- very strict on OT...demanded the same amount of work in an 8 hour period with no OT. Management not willing to change or bend on some of the goals. Rules were wishy-washy. It seemed to be different for one person to the other. Told that I would have to take a pay cut/move backwards to advance.

pros: Good Sales Training Program. Well recognized sales training program by other employers. Good stepping-stone to another job.
cons: Micro-managment to the death. Your manager will want to know everything about what you are doing because they don't trust you. Compensation for commissions and expenses arrived late on several occasions. Heard stories from other sales reps that managers would sandbag accounts from installing in order to benefit their pay and hurt their reps quarterly bonus. Worst part of the week is phone blocking. Phone blocking is where you sit in a cubicle for 4 hours and try to contact 100 people to set as many appointments as possible. Get used to rejection.

review_title: Manager with Cintas - First Aid and Safety Division
pros: Depending on the operation in which you work, it can be a good place, even a fun place to work.  If the local management team is good I believe most people would find Cintas to be a fair and enjoyable place to work.  For this to be the case however, you must be a fit with their typical profile.  By that I mean very competitive, money driven, promotion driven, whatever it takes attitude.  One of the best things I've seen during my many years with this company is that opportunities for career advancement are there for those that get results.  Additionally, Cintas has made a very strong committment to safety improvement over the past few years and it is having a positive impact on the well being of the employees.
cons:
Upper management is relentless.  The pressure they place on local managers is enormous.  That is part of the gig and I get it.  My main complaint is their approach and the way they go about gettng what they want (exceeding sales, profit, and growth numbers, perfect inventory, perfect receivables, perfect execution on pretty much everything).  Absolutely no recognition of what is going good and what you may be doing well.  Every ounce of focus is put on what you are doing wrong.  If you beat sales, beat profit, have great AR, but your new product sales are down...look out.  You will be berated and forced to explain why you are unable to produce results in that one area.  The tone is condescending and threatening.  It breeds resentment.  You are micro managed to the 10th degree.

What's worse is what upper management preaches about their fabled Corporate Culture.  Honesty, integrity, professionalism, treating employees like gold, and putting the customer first.  Such hypocrites, their perception of themselves is so skewed it's actually scary.  They preach it, but they certainly don't practice it.  Customers are taken advantage of.  Each rep walks into each customer for service knowing exactly how much money they need to get out of that customer in order to make their daily number.  There is no clearer example of Cintas first, customer second than that.  Clearly it's about what Cintas needs, not what the customer needs.  The customer is going to get as much product as the rep needs in order to make their number, it has nothing to do with what the customer actually needs.  Prices are ridiculous and price increases happen all the time with no advance notice to the customer base.

I will say that it wasn't always this way.  Top management in the division has made it this way.  Leadership is a thing of the past for the most part.  Now it's all accomplishing micro managed task after micro managed task.  Zero development of people, zero appreciation.  Hoperfully, this will swing back the other way at some point.

job_title: SSR Sanis Route in Wichita, KS
pros: Plenty of hours given, worked 50+ hours a week cleaning, had  full route, always given more work to do weekly. Lots of OT.
cons: Promised help/split route for 1 year, never happened, always next month. Management does NOT do what they promise. They EXPECT you to do what they ask IMMEDIATELY, but anything they promise can be withheld for as long as it suites them. They told me no more business on my route then put another job on it. Lies, lies, lies.

pros: Cintas is a strong company to work for and has been able to handle these challenging economic times.  There are some great people who work at the company who are very talented.
cons: The company does demand strong results and each partner to think like a business person.  I feel like that is a good thing but some people may view that as a negative.

review_title: A Company that doesn't invest in its people
job_title: Senior Corporate Accountant in Mason, OH
pros: Cintas provides its employees stable work hours, a great office environment and subsidizes a cafeteria in the corporate building for its employees.
cons: Cintas does not provide flexibility for its employees, is slow to change and does not invest in its people.  For accounts, specifically CPAs, the Company offers limited opportunities to obtain CPE credits.  I particularly was not impressed with the company culture.  For a large public company, I expected them to invest more in their people in order for them to grow and develop and did not find this with Cintas.

job_title: Service Manager in North Las Vegas, NV
pros: Interaction with customers and not pinned to a desk sometimes.
cons:
Service Manager should be renamed Sales Manager, the description of the position does not reflect the true nature of the position.
There's a bottleneck in upward movement, there are only so many locations in the rental division, with each location having 1-4 Service Managers. Multiply that by the number of locations (around 300), you have up to 1200 competitors for positions that may come open 1-2 times per year. This is not a position for anyone with aspirations to become someone with this company.

pros: Cintas attracts phenomonal talent. Working with such a talented and hard working group of people was very rewarding. The work is challenging as well and there is opportunity to learn and hone your skills in this fast-paced ever-changing environment.
cons: Cintas does not value diversity and intellectual property in their company. They give lip-service to diversity but age, gender and race are all factors in how people are valued and placed. Cintas once had a wonderful culture of hard-working, honest people whose contributions and tenure were truly valued by the founder and his leadership team. That has since changed as much of the tenured talent has left Cintas, taking the knowledge and day-to-day engagement of the culture with them. Top leadership has a tendancy to value people most like themselves, only younger versions that will accept long hours and hard work for significantly less pay then the hard working tenured workers who know and understand the culture and inner workings of the company and it's customers. Cintas puts on a good "image", after all, they are in the "image" business. But scratch just below the surface and you find a company fraught with politics, beauracacy, good-ol-boy cliques, no true diversity of style, personality and background of employees in leadership ranks, and an unrelenting drive to their primary goal of satisfying the shareholders (which top leadership are some of the largest) at all costs, even at the expense of the front-line employee jobs, pay as well as customers (over priced service, unbending contracts, oversold services that are company-centric, not customer-centric. This is most obvious with the decision to move many of it's jobs offshore to 3rd world countries, forsaking the community in Cincinnati that worked tirelessly for decades supporting their homegrown company.

review_title: Depends on who is running your branch
pros: Corporate is awesome and the people truly care out there but get into the branches and it seems like no one gives a hoot depending on your local GM, Sales manager.
cons: I had a crappy gm and the place sucked, then got an awesome gm who actually cared about his employees and people and the place was the best place to work, and it showed. Now once again our gm is a douche and the place sucks and our numberssuck.

review_title: Overall, not a bad place to work.
pros: The Partners are always the best part!  With hard work, there is a good potential to make good money.  The 4 day work week is the best!!!
cons: It's not always easy to sell catalog.  The commission is only 8%.  There should be a significant increase in the base pay to even things out.  Some SSR's are making a heck of a lot more money than others because of their routes.  It's not a fair system.

review_title: Very good company overall with a few miniscule problems.
pros: Best reason to work here is the people that you work with. Cintas will only hire people that fall into their corporate culture and that makes it a good place to work.
cons: I believe the front line partners are a little underpaid for the amount of work and hours they do. However, management is good about doing Partner Appreciation events and making the work environment a good one.

review_title: Very lean company viewed from a maintenance supervisor
pros: True team management experience, Fun/fast paced, good people, health insurance is great, team atmosphere
cons: Salaried personal are expected to do jobs that hourly people should be doing.  All salaried people are expected to work 60 hours a week.  Salaried supervisors are expected to cover their hourly guys vacations 100%.As maintenance sup, with 6 guys covering shifts starting at 330am and ending at 11pm, and each guy having 4 weeks of vacation, thats 24 weeks a year that you are pulling double duty.  It gets old very quickly.  Management is hit or miss.  My GM took 6 months to learn my name.  He has under 20 salaried personal.  My Plant manager was awesome but you can't complain to someone about working 60 hours a week when they are there before you and leave after you.  There isn't any work life balance, it is simply Cintas all the time.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Fair pay, good benefits. Many chances to earn commissions on product sales. There is a lot of freedom to do things your way.
cons: Horrible hours if you haven't paid your dues and worked up to a good route. Long days; mine were usually 12-14hrs. I had incompetent managers at the location I worked, but that will vary from place to place.

pros: Weekly check, benefits, like the coworkers and the 401 k is good because they match it. Working days helps so you have the rest of the day to chill out.
cons: Need to upgrade computer software, always crash, need to offer a more starting pay for the hard work that we do.

pros: Challenging, promote from within, make your own hours as long as the work gets done, recognition from upper management, great benefits, great pay, not a typical 9-5, family-like coworkers, competitive, the company spoils their high performers
cons: Over-complicated safety standards trying to reinvent the wheel, too worried about turnovers cintas would rather keep a low performer than fire him/her just so they dont have to explain to corporate why the partner had been let go, and the biggest complaint... no facial hair. Really nothing of high importance

pros: This company has a standard benefit package and pay scale which you would expect to find in any corporation of this size and type. You receive excellent health care, dependent care and retirement benefits.
cons:
The recruiting and hiring process is not completely transparent. I got an interview with management while transitioning out of the military. The position I applied for was listed as a specific city that I was interested in moving to and so the position was desirable to me. During the interview process, I made perfectly clear that I was leaving the military for geographical stability. When asked if I would be willing to move, I made it clear that I was not wanting to move for a number of years, despite the opportunities for promotion. I was offered the job in the city I wanted and I accepted it.

Once I began working, it became apparent that the position I was hired for did not actually exist and I was hired as "bench" in the event of management turnover, meaning that I had no value at the location where I was hired and was expected to move to somewhere else in the region. I was given work that was well below my capability level, simply to keep me busy. It was made perfectly clear to me that I was expected to move within a year. 

I would much rather have been told that our expectations did not match and not have received an offer, rather than wasting the time I did with them.

pros: Monday through Friday. Sometimes Monday through Thursday.  Weekly pay. Holidays off too.  Sometimes they have breakfast lunch and dinner once a month.
cons: Waiting one year to get one week vacation.   Very hard to move up in positions. Could be better with the pay

job_title: Uniform Room Attendant in Baltimore, MD
pros: Getting to know people. Actually doing the job hands on, working inside the casino, fitting new hires, learning new things
cons: The manager...you are not allowed to make mistakes, he hates to do his job, dont like being question, makes it uncomfortable for you to work. He is petty. He write quotes on the board for people to read if the situation happened between you and him. He find things to pick about and if he doesn't like you he will look for ways to write you up. Never been in anything back and forth with any managers nor fired until I met him. Never insubordinate, I always do what's asked but I get fired for not saving someone in the computer after being terminated. He lies and make it seem you are doing good or tell you something is not your fault and BAM! write up. The kicker... The woman I've worked with they dont even know what a write up looks like.

review_title: Great for leadership growth and opportunities
job_title: Service Sales Representative in Oakland, CA
pros: A great place to work on engaging with others around you building networking skills as well as people skills. A very diverse culture. Cintas is a leader amongst the rest of the linen industries with the service (SSR's service) we offer our customers. Great hours 4 day work week.
cons: Sometimes feeling replaceable only feeling like a numbered employee. Nastiness of the job and sometimes humbling. Having to deal with upset customers (customer service for the company), being the face of the companies customer service.

pros:
*PTO as soon as you get in the door. Prorated though.

*Opportunities to learn about the business through online training.

*Uniforms/Jackets/Boots. Nice perks. Especially for those who don't last a month. Boots are exceptional and expensive!
cons:
*Lies about growth. Plenty of people from this area with nothing on there records are called, or never called about the positions applied. When they weren't given the position, no answers were given, just an auto-generated e-mail stating we weren't chosen. 

*No incentive for cross training. Help out when needed as a team, even on equipment.

*Spartan mentality is strong here. They will listen, but no actions will be taken.

*Corporate rules with an iron fist. They bark orders without knowing the severity of the issue. Probably why they like hiring military people. Shut up and do it!

*Pay...Well, we all signed on the dotted line what we are worth. It is up to us to continue to grow and get what we are worth. Disappointing that when you try too, and how much they praise career opportunities at Cintas, nobody can leave.  Only two partners have been promoted in the warehouse a year ago with 40+ partners still wanting to advance. Very disappointed and HR is no help. Yes, some partners had bad records or have been written up, but myself, and a few others who have put in the time, know the products, and never miss a beat feel stuck. I only say that for my area only. Maybe at a different facility, you might have a chance. 

*HR, ineffective with the information they share. I will always recommend and everyone else will too, to double check the sources on the in-house website cause you will find A LOT of inconsistencies between what is announce through the meeting/conversation and what was signed off on the form online.

job_title: Management Trainee in Little Rock, AR
pros: The benefits are one of the best features of employment at Cintas.  My health insurance is second to none.  The support for a balance between my professional life and personal life is outstanding, even though long hours are sometimes needed to get my work done.  The people at my location are awesome to work with.  Opportunity for advancement is great!
cons: Salary partners sometimes work long, long hours.  The dental insurance is nothing to write home about, but still good.

review_title: Cintas is a great place to WORK, and WORK, and WORK
pros:
EXCELLENT benefits (medical, vision, life, dental, std, ltd, etc.)  - affordable also
EXCELLENT development
EXCELLENT corporate structure
Compensation is better than similar industry
cons:
It's a laundry business
You will work extremely hard
Compensation plans change annually
Several C-level position changes in the last few years

pros: Steady income, Four day work week, Benefits including health and retirement options, Decent wages compared to some competitors, Personal customer interaction
cons: Very limited opportunity for advancement, No incentive to work harder (the harder I work, the heavier my workload gets) Cintas pretends to care just enough to keep employees around, poor management at the production/service level (more training)

review_title: Cintas used to be a better place to work.....
pros:
Compensation - depending on your position (management or hourly) within the company.
Benefits (good medical & dental).
Co-workers.
cons:
Management - GM's are often too far removed from daily work situations.
Increased workload and decreased staff, which has caused more & more stress among employees.
Job descriptions changed a lot, resulting in my decision to leave Cintas.

job_title: Service Sales Representative in Cumberland, RI
pros: Stable job. Includes benefits for full time workers.
cons: Restructured employee pay  3 times in 6 years. I'm making approximately $7 kless than I did 2 years ago. Their annual reviews and salary structure is "obsolete" for the current economical state, on a local and national level. Completely unfair and unjust practices performed by management. The service rep in lower level workers always taking the fall for the axe of the upper management.

review_title: "Bleeding Blue" wears on you - You'll love your life after Cintas!
pros:
Benefits Good
Salary OK
Training Good 
Safety is Focus
cons:
If you're good at your job, be prepared to be abused!  The better you are, the more you will work!
You will often find yourself trying to find time for the family.
Team atmosphere is a facade.  Everyone is looking out for #1.

review_title: I love working at Cintas.  Our plant partners are hard working and our management team is most of the time supportive.
pros: Cintas takes it's culture very serious along with safety priority number one,  while being a very ethical company.  We all are very supportive of each other.  There's so many opportunities to make money in the SSR position.
cons: All service management partners should run a route for at least six months.

job_title: Warehouse Operations Supervisor in Vancouver, WA
pros: The guys that came from a company that  Cintas bought were top notch.
cons: Terrible management. Not bring told the truth from management. Not being  knowing what expected expected of you. Being written up for something your boss asked you to do and then changed their mind. Terrible safety manager.

review_title: CINTAS: Security, Great benifits, and good pay,mixed with no corporate humility.
job_title: Service Sales Representative in Madison, WI
pros:
Strong company, benefits are unbelievable.  4 day work weeks.  The amount of various services we provide is dazzling and impressive, and all the partners (co-workers) I've personally met are friendly and supportive. Cintas will promote from within but   The Management trainee program, however, used for a lot of jobs  including health and safety directors, division heads etc, don't have much OR USUALLY ANY experience in their fields.  Cintas requires a 4 year degree in anything to be a management trainee, so try to work for an inside promoted manager if you can. 

Employees are encouraged to run their route including scheduling with the customer and is pretty good at backing up what decisions you come up with. 

Cintas has a great free employee uniform program providing even work boots and jackets.
cons:
Company Motto is "We have a Spartan Approach".  That deciphers to stingy at times.  Sometimes things don't get repaired or replaced until it is broken and sometimes even dangerous.   Often it seems that company meetings, sales meetings and safety meetings are all you do.  It would be nice to get some work in between meetings, but that can be hard. 

 National policies NEVER update.  Even when common sense would dictate, some old rules and regulations are not updated.  Even in very hot climates employees are not allowed to wear shorts becuase our some of our customers employees didn't used to have that option.  We could actually make the shorts to Cintas specs since ALL employee apparel must be provided by Cintas to be in compliance.  The same happens in the cold, and rain.   You can be written up for wearing a raincoat, but CINTAS will not provide one for you.  


Salespeople are also driven hard and often oversell just to get the numbers up, then the Service Rep has to take the brunt of angry customers when they realize they are getting service more freqeuntly or excessively than they really need.

review_title: Good Training ground and development for your future
pros: Cintas offers great benefits including sales training and the pay is above average, the car allowance and expense reimbursement are fair as well. If you can find a mentor you can learn a lot about sales and how to build and run a territory. Cintas has a great name out there as far as recruiters and other companies that are looking for reps.
cons: Some times communication is not what it should be a company of this size. As with most larger companies you have to learn to play the office politics game.

review_title: Great entry-level positions, but hard to move up
pros: Ability to manage your own schedule, hit your goals to make pinnacle club (more $)
cons: No vacation in your first year....this is absolutely crazy. Certain managers micro-manage. If you do not make your sales goals, sometimes your hard work and diligence do not get recognized. If you are working hard and were not given the best route/territory - your pay will reflect that. Way behind the ball with technology. SSR's really could use a laptop/ipad/or at least reimburse >50% cell phone

review_title: Great until you get a little further up the ladder.
pros: Good money if you're a performer.
cons: Old boys club atmosphere in management. Nooooo diversity in sales upper management whatsoever. The glass ceiling is as thick as bulletproof glass. I can recommend this job only to my white male friends with aspirations of climbing the corporate ladder based upon their performance. I can't recommend with a straight face to my minority friends with the same aspirations because they WILL hit the glass ceiling eventually.

pros: You will learn a lot about service recovery. There are ample opportunities for advancement due to high turnover in leadership roles.
cons: You will get burned out dealing with the same recurring issues that are structural and cannot be fixed. Once you get into a leadership role, you will quickly discover why the turnover is so high.

job_title: SSR, STC, Production Manager in Syracuse, NY
pros: Good training, stable company, great co workers.  You can make real business decisions and make immediate impact.  A lot of lateral and vertical movement possible.
cons: Poor treatment of employees.  Most management is poorly chosen, and inexperienced.  Turnover is extremely high in all mid to upper management levels.  To be successful you have to either know the right people, or decline promotions and fly under radar.

review_title: Good company but definitely a grind at times
pros: Great training and support. Promote from within so opportunity to advance.
cons: Typical corporate structure. Lots of policies and top down initiatives as well as dinosaur age technology and computer systems. can feel like a drone at times. Also have to get dirty and do some of the tough jobs out on the trucks/in plant if you want to advance. Pay could be more.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Great River, NY
pros: Good benefits, nice people and regular hours
cons: You had to wear a shirt and tie to talk on the phone all day and not interact with customers.  If the upper management doesn't like you, they will find ways to make you un-promotable.  No paternity leave for men

review_title: Just one look inside the front door tells the story.....
job_title: Facility Services Sales Representative in London, ON
pros: None that I can think of, sales manager is high on himself and can't do what he preaches. Hence they can't keep and sales professionals and turn over is very high. Be prepared to get the false promises and pipe dream goals that are unrealistic. Big on "do as I say, don't do as I do"...
cons: Walking in the front door you are met with run down decor, stained carpeting, dust base boards, dull paint. The entire front office area looks like a run down welcome of filth like that in Mexico.

job_title: Office Administrator, Accounts Receivable, Acconunts Payable in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: the people are  wonderful to work with
cons: Doing way to many jobs. I am main Receptionist and custoemr service representative. I assist with Accounts Receivable, Accounts Payable, I order all supplies for the office, kitchen and document stroage. I am in charge of the non-inventory Purchase Orders and log book. I collect and deposit and log all cash and checks for invoices paid to the service representatives. Plus other odd and ends things.

job_title: Major Account Executive in Kansas City, MO
pros: I was able to do all the jobs that I ever dreamed of! TSE, Service Manager, District Sales Manager, National Account Executive, Major Account Executive. Always had the support of my peers and my management! I have met and worked with some incredible people! Fortunately I know from experience, Cintas is a great company and treats their partners with the utmost respect and they too employ great people. Great chance to work with some new rock stars.
cons: Unfortunately G&K is now no longer G&K. Due to the merger, many outstanding employees will be looking for employment elsewhere.

job_title: Facility Services Sales Representative in Austin, TX
pros: Autonomy. High ceiling for compensation. Company Car allowance
cons: Saturated market. Will have to work tirelessly just to stay afloat long enough to HOPE you can land a large contract in order to make real money. Not a good job for those who need structure and training and help to succeed. They want you to know how to run a business and run it for them no questions asked. If you cannot succeed you will be fired and replaced. Very high pressure.

review_title: Blue Collar Job With a Team Atmosphere
job_title: Service Sales Representative in Portland, OR
pros: Overall the company is stable - economic lulls aren't met with widespread layoffs.  You have a level of autonomy as far as what time you start your day and how you organize your deliveries and customer interaction.  With the right manager you are encouraged to make front line decisions on a lot of things.  There is no "I have to take this to my manager for approval" - you handle customer issues on the spot, and the better you are at selling yourself and your company, the more successful you will be.  You can go days, even weeks sometimes, without having to answer to a manager at all.  There is a concerted effort to make the company fun and playful in nature - by and large the people that work for the company are amazing.  I met a lot of good friends at the company over the years, people that I have continued to keep touch with, who still work there, and who have moved on.
cons: There is no union.  Your salary and commission structure may be changed at a whim, and your options are basically to either threaten to quit or just take the pay cut.  The program that the sales reps sell is not the same as what you are asked to do by management in the service department.  Example:  Sales reps key on excessive replacement charges from competitors, and state that Cintas doesn't do such a thing.  As a SSR, you are asked to charge the customer 20% of their revenue for replacement on every invoice to meet your job performance.  The downside of all the autonomy you get is the level of responsibility you have - sometimes the hours are very long when your goal is to have every customer very satisfied.  If you are unhappy, things will quickly grow very uncomfortable for you there - people are expected to always maintain a positive outlook regardless of what your situation is.

job_title: Market Sales Manager in Richmond, VA
pros: Most of the people that work for Cintas are wonderful people to work with.  The key word is "most"!! I have made life long friends with people there..
cons: First of all watch your back!! There are people there that will tell you one thing to your face then turn around and do or say another quite often.. I.E. the GM, OM/GM, Sales Directors and VP's. They talk about culture and taking care of the "Partners" ,thats the biggest joke in that place. It's all about the #'s and what have you done for me lately.

pros: Good starting salary but I doubt you will ever get a raise after that.
cons:
-No perks for any production employees at all. ( maybe the management do)
-Managers and supervisor cheat and lie in front of your face 
-Any production employees who work here for more than 8 years have the industries lowest pay. (Ask around)
-They pretend to be one of the safest place to work and the have a lot of BS paper work to prove it but in reality the are NOT. 
-VERY HIGH TURN-OVER RATE for both office and production employees

job_title: Associate Account Manager in Mason, OH
pros: Most people you work with will be good coworkers, respected company for your resume, valuable experience and training.
cons: Cintas pays well below what other companies do for the same job/work, profit sharing and monetary benefits are a joke when the numbers come in, they do not properly staff their teams.. There is a 'more with less' mentality.  Very close to fast food equivalent raises. Simply put there is no real value or appreciation shown to employees.

review_title: Good, if you are a relative...
pros: Great 401k.  When the company did well in sales, bonuses were great.  A lot of opportunities in the Cincinnati area.
cons: Lack of diversity within the company; even in urban areas.  Family members and friends of leaders were hired over qualified applicants creating rampant favoritism and leaders that were too scared to discipline employees because of who they were related to.  Pretty sad for a reputable company.

review_title: Great place to work. Terrible location
pros: great work/life balance. great money for the hours you work if  you are an SSR. The more you sell the more money you make
cons: Management at this location is terrible. There is no transparency. Very poor planning on scheduling around holidays which causes you to loose money. The sales team is very crooked, they will tell you everything you want to hear as long as they can line their pockets with money. Management care only about management not the SSR or the plant partners.

job_title: Advanced Management Partner in Miami, FL
pros: Friendly and inviting team that values integrity, honesty, and hard-work.  Very military / vet friendly corporation that appreciates those that have served our nation.  As a minority in this field of work, I have been treated with the utmost respect and dignity.  I am a valued member of this team and it is apparent from my interaction with my partners.
cons: Long hours (if you aren't use to them).  Onboarding was a bit disorganized, but still met the overall intent.

review_title: Oh the places you will go
pros: Car package and benefits are great.  You will learn a lot in the training 6 months into the sales job.
cons: starts out great for a few months, and then you learn the ins and outs of a huge company with a HUGE turnover rate. I've had 3 sales managers in one year! Very unorganized at times because you have so many people. And sometimes you have very little people.

pros: They think they send things to your home for your betterment when that’s what HR is for
cons: Too many chiefs and not enough Indians. Totally top heavy. Corporate people coming up with asinine ideas to justify their overinflated salaries. Don’t realize the customer comes first because they’re the ones that actually sign everyone’s pay check

review_title: I came in w/high hopes, but I was disappointed.
pros:
Good Health benefits
Vacation Time
Training Programs
cons:
Not everyone gets a yearly review like they're supposed to (mngmt forgets)
No successful career planning (they say they like to promote from w/in but don't prepare anyone)
Training programs are not followed up (rubber stamped training forms--employees just sign)
route drivers don't really take their lunches, their days are waaay too long to do so

job_title: Certified Route Trainer in Everett, WA
pros: Great training, opportunities, and for the most part professional people. The company's core values are family based. Team and individual recognition. attainable goals for compensation based commissions.
cons: Early start 4am, Highly competitive amongst employees, frequent change in management resulting in changing pay scales. Favoritism and nepotism with in the organization. Don't get injured unless you want to work some where else.

pros: Great Benefits. Not much else I like about this company
cons: "AR Department"  is actually a "collections department"  you are expected to make a minimum of 80 calls a day, to make collections call.  Accounts Receivable is very secondary.
